description: My secret hangout: good coffee, wifi and a beautiful view!
author: Mike T.

description:
The coffee is okay but the lady at the counter has the worst attitude ever. 
The staff has no idea what the dish is and the lady has no patient to explain the dish. And of course I can read the sign, I just want to know what it is! Even thought I already ordered what I want she still gave me this whatever look. It's just awful.
author: Fairy S.

description:
Such a rude and unprofessional customer service. I was there couple days ago with my friend. My friend bought a sandwich and we shared that together and then opened our laptops to work. The woman who was working there came to me after a while and asked me if I don't wanna buy anything from them in a very rude and unpleasant way. I told her we are together and my friend bought something and we shared. Then she said your friend did and why you don't buy.  I explained for her again that we are together and we just needed one sandwich to share cause I'm not that much hungry . And I told her that's so weird. Suddenly she started to yell at me "what's so weird?!!!! Go out if you don't want buy anything". Her behavior was very very rude and bothered us and all people who were at the cafe at that time. 
I think it's better for her to retrain and think about her behavior to not loose the business!
author: Noushin P.

description: Good environment. Good service. They make food very fast. No need to Waite. Toilet is clean. Orange juice is fresh. Another customers are usually come often. No strange people.
author: Pei-Lun H.

description: Coffee was decent and they were quick for my to go cold brew. There wasn't a line and they were polite. If anything, nothing significant about the experience to call out.
author: Brandon B.

description: Here is great place for take a break  relax yourself or with friends and family  get a cup of coffee & tea or other drinks; sandwich and the baked food, barista are very nice, coffee and foods are very good
author: Yun Z.

description: Good coffee, they play great music and it has a nice ambiance! A good place to take a little break.
author: Daan H.

description: Such a convenient place to come and get a sandwich or coffee since I live right down the street. The sandwiches are delicious and the coffee isn't bad either.  3 stars because It is definitely pricier than other coffee stops and since it is a "neighborhood" joint, I've noticed they can sometimes act 'cliquey' to people who aren't every day regulars which sucks.
author: Luke E.

description:
Simply rude. I was waiting for a student because he wanted to meet there and grab something to eat. Girl comes up to me and tells me that if she can help me with something. I told her what I said earlier and she said, "this is for customers only". Kicks me out. 

CULERA. CULERO. CULEROS.
author: Benjamin K.

description: Love their bagel and cream cheese. The price is worth paying because the food is great.
author: Leticia S.

description:
NASTY SERVICE 

Seriously perplexed why this pace has 3.5 stars. I don't think I've ever encountered being sworn at in an eat-in, even if its of the lowest quality. I came in with my 5 year old son and because the women at the counter didn't understand what a ciabatta roll is (which is on their menu) she became irritated and annoyed. I then decided to not order and leave. On my way out with my son, she lashed out with verbal abuse at me and told me to get the FUCK OUT!!!! I was so completely shocked by her verbal attack, especially in front of my 5 year old son and other customers including young children.  Has anybody had a similar experience??? Is this the typical service you get here? I looked around the place before I ordered and you can tell the place is unhygienic and the portions were tiny. Not sure why the place still exist as a business. So glad I didn't order here. Save your dignity and money and head down the road to a proper sandwich place Turners Kitchen just 1 minute away, who know what they are doing. What a nasty ignorant uncontrollable angry women.
author: Kimberleu H.

description: Came here to take a break before we headed home, but the service and the Vietnamese cold coffee was alright--nothing to special. It is a nice place to study though.
author: Nishi S.

description: If you're the type of person who freaks out over your coffee taking longer than 30 seconds to be prepared or your barista not having the demeanor of a kindergarten teacher, you might be better off elsewhere. This spot is a family owned neighbor gem of over a decade with genuine hard working employees. The location is beautiful, plenty of space to work, and consistently delicious food & drinks. I'll proudly pick them over the bougie new spots up the street any day!
author: Tina P.

description: Downloaded Yelp just for this review. I used to think this place was fine but after repeatedly bad customer service stopped coming in. I do laundry next door and was in desperate need of a drink. Not only did the person behind the counter mess up my drink -- not making it iced, but then she wanted to charge me 50 cents more for a to go cup of ice when I already got charged for the original to go cup. I would rather be thirsty than support this business.
author: Rachel B.

description: Meh, wannabe hipster cafe. Mismatched tables and furniture in a community style layout where people can sit and go on their laptops. The lady at the cashier was a little stuck up and barely cracked a smile. I ordered 2 medium cold brews for $7 but they were pretty watered down. If you held it up, you could see it was pretty light so not sure if they just added water to it. Kind of disappointed...barely any flavor too.
author: Marissa C.

description:
Sweet people work here, it's a neighborhood coffee shop with regulars and great foot traffic from the park.  Plenty of outlets to work, reliable wifi, 4 outdoor tables for nice days, and great sandwiches!

PLUS, they sell beer and wine for when you want to reward yourself when it's time to put away your laptop :)
author: Ben G.

description: Terrible customer service. They started our drink before we finished our order, we changed our order and got 10 eye rolls our way. The cashier was impatient and rude and kept saying "we already made it" with an attitude when she hadn't even charged us. My mom has an accent and the cashier kept looking at her as if she didn't want to deal with her when the lady barely speaks english herself.
author: Carla B.

description: I've been in many cafe's in San Francisco but have never come across such rudeness and bad customer service. Despite their watered down coffee I came back again thinking that perhaps the counter people had a bad day and that things would be different this time, but unfortunately that's just their personality and how they do business.
author: Anil S.

description:
I haven't had alot done at this location since it was my first time dropping by but the service was super nice, ease of ordering and paying so I would come back if i'm in town again.

The coffee tasted nice and the place is awesome for friends to get together before heading out.

the place had huge open space and comfy couches with patio tables outside.  Pet friendly and free wifi.

awesome!
author: Anthony L.

description: This is a neighborhood, family run coffee shop that's great for a good cup of joe and a decent place to sit. No frills and their breakfast bagel sandwich is perfection.
author: Samia B.

description: The chai latter served in a giant mug is what did it for me. Also great prices and comfortable atmosphere.
author: Peter B.

description: My husband and I were on vacation in San Francisco and bumped into this place while exploring and checking out the mission District. I ordered a Matcha green tea that was amazing. My husband also really enjoyed his vanilla chai latte. Very low key easy vibe. No frills but good for a hot drink or mid day snack!!
author: Aliyah B.

description: Some of the baristas are really nice and very attentive but the owner has an attitude problem, has poor customer service skills.
author: Karl H.

description: This coffee shop is conveniently located near my summer school site, and as a teacher, I need my morning cup of coffee. Every day I come in, the staff are incredibly rude... same 2 people day in day out, and I figured the first time maybe it was just an off day... but we are on three weeks now! I guess customer service isn't important- but the food is lousy, over priced, as is the coffee! I can't wait until summer school is over so I never have to walk in here again. I don't even want to continue to give them business, but they are in luck because I need coffee. Very dissatisfied customer.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Service here is really poor. The baristas are really rude, and on a few occasions they've deliberately charged more than the actual cost of the drink. No one wears gloves when they're preparing food, which is pretty gross.
author: Alex G.

description: Terrible service.  I was charged twice for the same order. Then the counter person tried to fix it, but I was then charged an additional $.  When I came home to check my bank account. There were three charges and no refund.  I'll have to call the bank now to get two of these charges removed.  They really need to hire someone who can run a cash register correctly.
author: Katharine B.

description: Everytime I come here which is seldomly I get a coffee and or a snack. It's usually pretty packed with people on their laptops or reading books. People working there have always been nice. I once ordered a bagel sandwich as well which was very inexpensive and delicious.  The coffee tasted good, I got a slice of banana bread the other day which was tasty. Cute coffee shop that I hope sticks around considering the neighborhood has been changing so rapidly.
author: Francesca D.

description:
Upon looking at the place from outside we decided to give this place a try. We were visiting San Fran and wanted to explore different parks and coffee shops. The place looked very cute and trendy on the outside so we decided to stop by. Parking is a little difficult but that is expected in a city such as San Fransisco. We ordered two lattes, exactly the same with one non fat milk and he other with almond milk. Both had the same flavor, hazelnut. Each drink was made without flavor and we sent them back. The owner was very rude and told us she hadn't charged us for flavor. Her mistake. So we explained how we both ordered the same drink but with different types of milk and she argued with us. Then she poured another latte with nonfat milk and told us it was almond. My friend is a vegan and milk really makes her sick. So I asked for her to make the next with almond milk and both women were super angry and told us we were wrong and didn't order it like that. 

To top it off, the coffee was average. Nothing really special and the service was not good. Definitely wouldn't recommend to people traveling but maybe as a spot for locals to work and do homework.
author: Kelly W.

description: I ordered the club sandwich, turkey sandwich, hot chocolate, soy chai latte, and a couple cookies. My grandma and I enjoyed our meal and we are impressed by how fresh the ingredients are in the sandwiches! Good job! The drinks and cookies were also delicious. Thank you!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Totally average coffee and drinks, but a pleasant place to hang out thanks to free wifi and a corner storefront that offers a nice view of the surrounding neighborhood.

Indeed, the key advantage here is the prime location in between the Castro and the Mission, just steps away from Dolores Park. The main drawback: it's almost always crowded here, with people camping out over their laptops all day long. With the crowds, this place can really heat up on a warm day, or whenever the sun's shining through.

Not a bad choice for some grab-and-go if you live in the immediate area though.
author: Vincent L.

description: Nice place to work, great location, yummy sandwiches, plenty of outlets and wifi.
author: J P.

description:
I love this neighborhood cafe. Good coffee, wonderful freshly squeezed OJ, beer and wine. Smoothies. All good. Nice, efficient, and friendly service in a clean and welcoming atmosphere.
The baked goods are yummy, but the sandwiches, especially the BLT, wins the blue ribbon. Absolutely delicious. Crispy bacon, crunchy lettuce, and delicious tomatoes. Perfect amount of mayo.
Thank you Maxfields!!!!!
author: Jane L.

description:
Attractive open plan with plenty of space for quiet workers and social butterflies. Guess what? They actually had DECAF Vietnamese Iced Coffee...no one ever has that! I mean, do you really think the whole Vietnamese diaspora seeks to be caffeinated? 

I digress. 

Wifi was good, breakfast bagel was good too. Easier parking than much of the Mission district.
author: Gina F.

description:
I come here quite often since I live just around the corner.

The main thing that keeps me coming back is their bagels and the fact that they have real fresh-squeezed orange juice, made to order on the spot.

Especially their veggie bagel is a favorite of mine. But the lox bagel is really good as well.

It is also very quiet so a nice place to chill in the morning or spend some time online.
author: Jonas S.

description:
Ooh no! First sign of failure was the scent of burned coffee in the air. The second which happened rather quickly was when I ordered a Cappuccino. When everyone else in The City is charging $4.50, their rates are excellent at $2.85. Unfortunately there is a $5.00 minimum for cards *sigh*. I wasn't hungry so I chose not to order any unnecessary extras. No coffee for you Lady J!

In a last ditch effort I asked for water. I was directed to a cabinet which had stacked plastic cups that were not fully dry, sitting on a dusty shelf. I could see the dust!!!

This review started with 2 stars. After my tutor arrived the cashier came over to inform us that if we wanted to stay, we needed to order something. 1 star deleted.

I think I will be having my French lessons elsewhere thank you very much.
author: Jaylena P.

description:
There is a glumness in the service to be experienced at Maxfield's, and one can only surmise there have been a lot of caffeine-fueled battles over the availability of free WiFi which have left the servers shell-shocked and unable to break a smile to neophyte visitors like myself. That's too bad because I like the space here, a casual hipster/thrift-shop gallery vibe with plenty of tables for long-term laptoppers in need of self-absorption (see photos). Of course that's probably part of the problem since the owners probably need to use a well-greased spatula to get some of them to get out of their chairs, and considering their five o'clock shadows, I don't believe personal hygiene is a priority for them. And I'm just talking about the women.

Proximity to Dolores Park, the Castro and the Mission make this an attractive spot for a caffeine pick-me-up, and prices appear to be in the standardized Starbucks range, for example, $1.95 for a large coffee. It was nothing that would keep Phil up at night, but it did keep me upright for the short walk to the park. Perhaps to their chagrin, they also serve food here beyond the predictable selection of pastries - quiches, piroshkis, four sandwiches, a slice of spanikopita and a soup de jour. All appear reasonably priced in case you want to hold a marathon blogging session. I've been reading about a singing barista, but there was nary a peep from the staff when I was there, just the hyped-up keyboard tapping you would expect in a designated house of caffeine.

COFFEE - 3 stars...standard cup of joe with standard pricing
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...a potentially cool space, but the populace hardly moves
SERVICE - 2 stars...pretty surly...should I take it personally?
TOTAL - 3 stars...a convenient coffee stop on the way to Dolores Park and not much more
author: Ed U.

description: Down to Earth cafe. Breath of fresh air and throwback to the 90's Mission. Chill here before exploring the spectacular Dolores Park.
author: Elise C.

description: Not the warmest staff. But the place is spacious enough to bring your laptop to and get some work done. Plus, it's conveniently located near Dolores Park. On a nice day, outside tables proved to be perfect for people (and dog) watching.
author: Yad L.

description: I like this coffee shop because it has a timeless feel, much less sterile than some of the other new cafes nearby. The coffee has been good (although I do not "know my coffee"). The baristas are cool and nice. This is a pretty good place to work.
author: Noah S.

description:
Plethora of coffee and food, free WiFi, and delightful music? Totally fell in love with Maxfield 's at first sight. It's easy to order food and drinks at the counter (though I haven't tried the food yet) but I just got a Thai tea since I already had too much caffeine in one day. This place has a homey feeling to it, from the service and vibe, to the decor and high ceilings. 

Few housekeeping items... credit card minimum is $5 and remember to ask for the WiFi password when you pay. Not much else to add. Solid place to grab some coffee and get some work done in a peaceful environment.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Prices listed on menu are different than what is charged by the restaurant. They got mad that I asked for a bag to put my sandwich in and tried to charge 10 cents for a tiny bag. I don't mind the SF bag charge for grocery bags but they were just trying to be rude and cause undue hassle. Also the sandwich I had the turkey club was not very good very low cost ingredients and the turkey seemed off.
author: Meghan A.

description: Not a bad cafe to get some work done. Wifi is on the slower side (3.26d/1.65u), and there are few outlets, but there's a lot of seating. Actually pretty crowded on a Sunday afternoon, but plenty of seat options closer to 5pm. $3.25 for a decent sweet chai, nothing special, and sweeter than I would go fore.
author: Linus W.

description:
Laptop camper here. Maxfield's has a great location close to Dolores Park and laid back vibe. You can hang out inside or outside. It's a decent, fairly typical coffeehouse. 

I do love their art - the Hanna Barbera cartoon character paintings they had for sale.
There are plenty of eats to be had, including sandwiches, bagels, pastries, vegan cookies, quiche, empanadas, quiche and burritos. Beer and wine are available.

* Veggie bagel: Like that it had plenty of fresh veggies.
* Coffee: Not bad, not great. The latte wasn't rich but it wasn't bitter either. There was no foam art.

To access the free wi-fi ask for the password at the counter. There are ample power outlets and it's a pretty quiet place where you're likely to find a laptop camper.

I like the high ceilings. The interior has an independent coffeehouse look with mismatched furniture.

Cash only. ATM on site. 

You know you love me. X0 X0, laptop camper.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Worst latte I've had. Tastes like water and served in a water glass. Really uniquely bad in taste. Also a 6 minimum on cards.

There are too many other good shops nearby if you're looking for decent coffee.

Otherwise it has a lot of space and working Internet.
author: Nathan W.

description:
I'm changing my review based on new interactions! I had had a really upsetting experience connecting to the internet, but it seems like they changed the way you connect, and everything is fine now. It may have been a bad day and everyone seems nice now. Plus they are very clean, really really clean and the music is amazing; its like Gen X Easy Listening:

Smooth Operator-Sade
Power of Goodbye- madonna
Time after time - cyndi lauper
Would I lie to you - eurythmics
End of Innocence - Enigma(?)
I wanna fall in love - Chris isaac
Thompson Twins (something)
Sting - if i ever lose my faith in you
With or without you - U2
One way or another - Blondie
author: Carrie H.

description: Ridiculous to have a $5 minimum if you have square! If someone wants to order one coffee just let them, it will cost you business. Don't really like the coffee either.
author: Vincent V.

description:
I used to patronize this spot as a courtesy to the neighborhood; decent coffee, sandwiches, drinks, pastries, and the like in the hopes of it not one day turning into a Baby Gap. I don't have a baby but Baby Gap doesn't sound so bad any more.  

I may not know the owners by name, but the two women who are always there I'm sure have enough facial recognition skill to realize that I live in the neighborhood and at one point would go in about once a week.  

Some months back I was doing my laundry next door and decided to go in and relax for 20 minutes while my clothes were drying.  I do not freeload at coffee shops, most especially, the ones which are local family businesses.  I was about to eat dinner and thought it prudent to buy a water and banana, and spend the remainder of time trekking through Email City....

Not even 10 minutes after finishing my banana did one of the proprietors shoot me some epic stink eye, waltzes over and says: "Are you waiting for someone here? If not, in order to stay, you have to buy more stuff".  

My shock was matched by the expressions of people around me.  I was embarrassed for myself, and the gamut of looks on the other customers' faces was everything from sympathy to anger.  I quickly left and haven't looked back since.  

As a small business owner it isn't necessary to learn your regulars names, or even what they usually order.  What is necessary though is having the decency to treat everyone that enters with an ounce of respect and realize no matter how little or great of quantities of product they decide to buy on a given day, If you do right by them you gain a customer for life.  Sadly I won't be one of them.
author: Ovidio C.

description: Coffee is nothing special but cheap for a breakfast bagel if your passing by. Sandwiches are tasty too. Usually filled with people on their laptops and open all hours, just don't expect a great cup of coffee.
author: Allie S.

description:
wifi password: maxcoffee

great food, simple cafe, great place to do work, fresh squeezed OJ is a plus
author: Emehleigh R.

description:
Just awful. 

It's hard to believe, with so many good cafes in the neighborhood, that Maxfield's can survive with its mediocre products, inflated prices, and the owners' contempt for customers. 

They can continue to impress others with their supercilious demeanor and gloomy atmosphere, I won't be back.

I'll be happy to bring my business to the much more alive Dolores Cafe, or friendly Morning Dew, both within a minute or two walking.
author: Jonah H.

description:
The cashier was aggressive and rude about telling me to leave just because I did not make a purchase from their establishment. All I was doing was waiting for my laundry to finish next door and thought I could do some studying while I waited.

Just a heads up, don't bring anything that isn't from their store or they will kick you out without even being courteous about it.
author: Reymark R.

description:
Had the privilege of being able to work off-site today and I stumbled upon Maxfield's in an effort to find free wifi. What you will find here is a nice neighborhood cafe with the usual coffee products, sodas, sandwiches, muffins/cookies and beer. What was truly nice about this establishment was the reliable wifi and the abundance of power outlets! I found the place to be relatively quiet on a Wednesday morning which helped my productivity. Outdoor seating is available as well. 

In terms of the food, I enjoyed their avacado sandwich.  At $6.75 I thought it was fairly priced especially with regards to their portion size generosity. Note that their credit card minimum is $5, which is fair.

Regarding overall ambience, it isn't the most modern of designs, but it gets the job done. The inside does get a little warm, especially on a nice sunny day during the middle of SF Indian Summer. 

In general, I would recommend this place as a great spot to hang out for a little bit, enjoy some beverage, and maybe get some work done if you're focused enough to do so.
author: Kavi D.

description: This place is a good spot to kick it, WiFi, study nice area but I simply ordered hot latte with caramel and the batista "Steve" took my order did not smile, was very inpatient and when I got my coffee it was iced, did not have caramel so I think I will take my business elsewhere. Need better batista and smile a little.
author: Roniel R.

description:
Great location, plenty of room inside, but the service is horrible. Baristas will treat you as if they're forced to serve you.
The food, drinks, and snacks options are decent, but like many other people said, the staff is extremely rude. Just a suggestion to the owner and rest of the staff... It wouldnt kill you to treat your customers nicely with respect and with a smile :-) try it out... Im sure it'll help your business and you'll get better tips!
author: Miguel A.

description: Worst service for a simple cafe spot.  Too bad since it's such a good location.  Walk over to church st and market st to Church street cafe for better coffee, food, ambiance, and most importantly CUSTOMER SERVICE.  Maxfields if u wanna keep a good cafe in a good location hire better baristas to run your spot.
author: Kalia N.

description:
Location location location
Great place to sit outside and people watch.
Coffee is not bad, but their sandwich are great.
Fresh oj is also yummy.
author: Tsu C.

description: Great neighborhood coffee shop and very reasonable prices. I ordered an iced Americano and it's good but a pretty weak, I'm sure you could ask for a smaller cup or less water if you like your Americanos stronger! Only $2.45, which is a steal compared to most coffee shops in the Mission. The breakfast sandwiches also look legit, I'll have to try one next time.
author: Lauren G.

description:
They have a wide selection of drinks and snacks, but the items I've bought have been hit or miss...

Soy Latte:  Hit
Chai Latte:  Miss
Cream Cheese Muffin:  Miss
author: Jeff B.

description: Little gem in the mission great for studying or catching up with friends. The wifi always works, the drinks are affordable and the sandwiches clean and tasty! There are lots of tables and there are windows with great light so you don't feel like you are indoors. Remember to bring cash for purchases under $5! Only bummer is they could beef up their cappuccino making skills.
author: Rachel H.

description:
I'm a regular at Maxfields and I really like coming here for the following reasons.

Lots of drink options: They have your standard coffee drinks, a wide selection of bag teas, bottled drinks, fresh oj, beer wine and blended drinks for people who are into that sort of thing.

Solid food:  The have good breakfast sandwiches, standard lunch sandwiches, bagels, wraps,  fruit, and pastries. Some people have complained about cookies being stale.  They don't make their cookies, they get them from local bakers so I don't quite understand that complaint. All the cookies and pastries are wrapped in plastic or covered so I think Maxfield's is doing their best to preserve their freshness

Lots of natural light: The front of the cafe is almost all windows so natural lighting fills the space until late afternoon/evening when the overhead lights fill in. The natural light is great when I'm reading books and is nice since I'm on my laptop most of the time i'm there. 

Lots of seating: they have a good variety of seating, small, medium and large tables and a few couches that can meet the needs of individuals and big groups. 

Lots of power outlets: Like I mentioned I work on my laptop and it is very rare when I can't plug in if I need to.  Power is accessible from almost every seat in the cafe save a couple. 

Free-ish wi-fi: The wi-fi is free for customers and reliable. Once in a blue moon the internet will slow down, usually when the cafe is full of computer users, or just hasn't worked but the staff have quickly remedied the problem when it's brought to their attention. The wi-fi seems to be an issue with some reviewers  so i'm going to reiterate what I said before, the wi-fi is free for customers. This means if your buddy shows up and whips out his macbook the staff is going to ask him to buy something.  This is a reasonable request.

Solid service: Morning, afternoon or evening the service is quick and accurate.  The only time my order gets delayed is when a few people before me have ordered espresso drinks or there are a bunch of sandwich orders before mine.  And when they aren't busy they will even bring your food to you if they know where you are sitting.  

The comments about the baristas being rude or that they hate their life are way off the mark.  Sure some of the ladies that work here can be curt but its a cultural thing.  They are not trying to be rude but they are also not going to coddle you, hold your hand while you order and become your BFF the first time you walk in the door.  If you want that kind of place this isn't it.  If you come here regularly and you want to chat and get to know them your're going to have to initiate things the first few times.  

Ultimately, Maxfields is an unpretentious neighborhood cafe that has everything I need during a days work and the more I come the more I've come to enjoy the people who work here and the the regulars who help give it its particular character.
author: Eric Z.

description:
Maxfield's is a cozy coffee shop in a popular area and around the corner from Dolores Park. Its a great place to pick up some cold drinks and sandwiches. Inside you'll see some cool decor paintings paying homage to old school Cartoon Network-style drawings, and they offer Wifi for customers as well.

I usually opt for a caramel macchiato (a perfect balance of sweetness and coffee) or Vietnamese iced coffee, but their drink options extend beyond coffee. The staff who work behind the counter are always friendly and efficient, and they recognize regulars who live in the area.

Its a great change from the same old copy-and-paste chain coffee shops - you won't be disappointed.
author: Felix C.

description: Best BLT ever. Fresh, clean and the staff is laid back and nice. Easy parking and wifi too.
author: Dominique R.

description: Not over the top or exceptionally unique but still sweet and charming. In the nook of the Mission without being flooded by overzealous weekend energy. The perfect place to park my seat and settle into some tea while catching up on homework and people-watching.
author: Chris S.

description: Great coffee and fresh orange juice.
author: Maria S.

description:
Very disappointing.

I tried two items at this spot:

Peanut Butter Chocolate Chip Cookie - not good at all: dry, somewhat flavorless and no real taste of chocolate.  Usually when I buy something, I'll still finish it, but it really wasn't worth the calories.

Thai Iced Tea - another disappointment...it had the basic flavor one would expect, but it definitely wasn't sweet enough...it really tasted like tea with some cream.

This place is pretty big and with the tall ceilings, it makes it seem even bigger.  When you first walk in here, you feel like you're stepping back in time to 1991, when most coffee houses looked like this...it just doesn't work for what's current in San Francisco.  There is some outdoor seating, which is nice on a sunny and warm day.  If you're coming here for to relax and read, I'd say stick to the bottled beverages since the two items I tried were not very good at all.
author: Ken G.

description:
Very rude owner. Went there 3 times in 3 days and every time I needed to use the restroom, some idiot behind the counter would ask me: "are you a customer?" with a suspicious look on their face. Great way to treat people. 

Today, I told them that I was no longer a customer.
author: El P.

description:
As several other reviews have mentioned, the service leaves something to be desired and the food and coffee isn't good enough to make up for the poor service. 

I'm a semi-regular here simply because I live so close, but I'm never treated like one and there's no sense of community here like there is at the many other coffee shops in Mission Dolores. After a negative experience with the owner and barista, I've finally decided that I'm going to be avoiding Maxfield's for good.
author: Ali G.

description:
Airy big space with lots of windows for sunlit studying. I think of it as Mercury Cafe and Church Street Cafe's love child. 

Decent coffee, though the asian ladies working the counter seem ready to assert their surly selves. 

Plenty of seating, lots of outlets, free wifi. DONE.

Bathroom graffiti is also kind of awesome. Highlights are "East Bay people are the best...for me to poop on" and "I am a Cathedral."
author: Kevin L.

description: cute, busy, local!  Had a coffee date here (and hell didn't even freeze over) here and the place was buzzing on a Sunday afternoon. I wish I was buzzing since my date was helluva boring. Meanwhile, had a cookie, a little dry, best to sick with the coffee drinks because hell It's a coffee house.  No second cup of coffee and no second date :-/
author: Michael C.

description: After touring SF Mission Delores, this is good stop to just to grab a cup of coffee within walking distance. No need to move car since off street parking is tight in this neighborhood. Drinks are okay and prices lower than name brand coffee house (starbucks, peets).
author: Clifford W.

description:
Agree with the other reviewers on here in terms of poor service with belligerent baristas. 

Positives: never crowded, plenty of outlets, relatively quiet.

Negative: Came here on first day and couldn't eat my snack and had to take it outside. Second time, was asked to put my Odwalla juice bottle away. Third time, she came with a scary smile and said "Here's my policy, you have to order something immediately when you come in, you can't wait to order it" even though I told her I was going to buy a sandwich after I settled down. 

Scary scary owners, will probably never come back.
author: Susie Y.

description: Great local spot to get coffee. They have very standard lunch and breakfast sandwiches as well. They also have beer (on tap) and wine, which is awesome. They open slightly earlier than other coffee shops in the area which I greatly appreciate. There is also outdoor seating. Sometimes we do laundry at the laundry mat next door and grab a glass of wine/beer in between washing and drying. This spot definitely has a consistent group of regulars but is never so busy that you cannot find a spot.
author: Juliet S.

description: I go here pretty much weekly. It's a great place, casual atmosphere, decent food. Good coffee.
author: Asad R.

description: I live very close and come here probably once or twice a week. They are inexpensive, great location, free wifi and have great food (especially the veggie bagel). I've always had neutral experiences with the baristas. Not friendly but not rude. After reading the reviews I will agree that the woman that owns the place (at least I believe she owns it) can be kind of abrasive. I've seen her be short with people and she's been short with me on occasions. Especially about the 5 dollar credit card limit. I understand that lots of places in the mission only take cash or have a limit, but when you're a coffee shop it really seems like a poor business decision to not accommodate the people who just want their morning coffee. I've learned to bring cash with me or order something to eat with my beverage. Otherwise I think this place is great. The patio is always pleasant and the big glass windows make it a nice location to sit down and do some work. Plus it's never overly crowded like the other cafés directly next to Dolores Park.
author: Shmev R.

description: God forbid that you take a moment to settle in before ordering else the nazi lady in the front will approach you at your table and force you to order something. I'm actually a regular here, but she still doesn't recognize me or treat me like one. So yeah.. if you're looking a place where you'll be appreciated as a customer, don't come here.
author: Henry W.

description:
I started visiting Maxfield's in April of last year and it quickly became a staple of my San Francisco visits. I love to find a spot, buy a few coffees and a croissant sandwich and soak in the environment. The place is always sunny and full of light. There are local artists featured on the walls in an ever-changing gallery. There is a waling tour group that comes through every day around 12:30, so there's amazing people-watching fodder on a regular basis. And the barista plays an eclectic mix of sing-alongable music that seems to really drive home the carefree and joyful vibe this city is famous for. 

The fare is standard for San Francisco coffee shops, but I truly love the distinct character of this space. Whenever I have 'office' work to do, it always happens here.
author: Andrew D.

description:
Maxfield's House of Caffeine is a convenient place to grab a cup of coffee and a cookie (I am addicted to the Healthy Nut Cookies) and hang out a bit. Sadly, the service leaves a lot to be desired. Typically, there is only one barista working behind the counter, and she tends to move very slowly regardless of the number of people waiting in line. Of course, this place isn't the place to be if you're in a hurry...it's a place to hangout...surf the net, read a book, or chat with friends. Nonetheless, I am a bit old school and believe in fast and FRIENDLY service. Although the baristas have never been rude to me, they have never gone out of their way to be friendly either. 

As other reviewers have indicated, you certainly will not be wowed by the coffee. But, Maxfield's is a good place to stop for a cup of joe on your way to Dolores Park.... I like to sit outside and people-watch.
author: Jerome I.

description: This a very nice place to either sit down and do work (read: quite and free wifi for paying customers). There seemed to be plenty of seating available, so it wasn't hard to find a spot. I wasn't overly impressed with their Iced Mocha, but the fresh squeezed orange juice was absolutely delicious. Once I tried that, I forgot all about the coffee. I haven't had a chance to try their sandwiches, but the cookies were delicious.
author: Bryan M.

description:
Following a walk through the old Mission Dolores church, I needed a bit of a pick me up for the afternoon. While aimlessly walking around and searching for a Starbucks, I happened upon a sign that said, "House of Caffeine." Much like a (self-proclaimed) trendy teen to an A&F store, I gleefully hopped in to get a cup of joe.

Ambiance was like a hipster coffee shop where I would expect beatnik drums and poetry at night. The coffee was a cup of sludge - the brew so strong that even a spoonful of sugar didn't even pierce the taste of the brew. Don't take it as a complaint - it was exactly what the doctor didn't order, which for those who know me for more than five minutes can attest, is exactly what I will go for. 

Not a very accessible place unless you're from the neighborhood, which I'm sure the folks sponging the internet prefer, otherwise it would get a higher rating.
author: Jake K.

description: This place has everything...tea, coffee, beer, food, and more importantly, *vegan* baked goods. Also it happens to be near that huge patch of green where herds of people congregate everyday. That being said, it's usually pretty busy and you might not get a seat if you're with a few people. But grab a coffee or tea and some food to go anyway, because you know you want to hang out at Dolores until the fog starts coming through.
author: Jon T.

description:
All the women here are equipped with the worst attitudes and facial expressions. I swear that one of them have a permanent scowl on. It sucks because it's such a cool coffee shop to chill and do homework at. I know several people who have had terrible experiences with these ladies and swore to have never come back.

You could be the sweetest customer coming up to order something and they still wouldn't return a smile. They look like they hate their lives and they hate you.The menu is very limited, sandwiches are okay but nothing for vegans/vegetarians/gluten-free eaters. There's no healthy alternatives and the only thing that's pretty decent is the Odwalla and teas (very limited still). 

I'd skip this place and go down to Church Cafe.. wayy nicer people and a good place to study.
author: Leelee E.

description: Before describing how good the coffee is here I must say that I have been astonished by how rude the owner is. This place has the potential to be one of the top coffee shops in San Francisco but that could start only as the clients are treated in a different way. Once that happens, things will be different. As I said before, this place has the potential; great coffee, great food, great location, but still service has not been able to match the positive things.
author: Stacie P.

description: The two older women who work there have a lot to learn about customer service and diplomacy. In the hour I was there, I witness them go up to customers who just got there less than 15 minutes to ask them to order something - both customers were getting settled and was getting ready to go order. I understand they want to make sure people don't come just to use their wifi but there's a way to say these things without being rude. I don't want to give my money to a place like this. Yuck.
author: None o.

description:
pros: outlets, daylight, long hours, lots of food & bev options including beer, spacious w/plenty of seating.

cons: a little noisy, you might hate the music (if you hate Enya, which I don't), 1/2 of the ownership team seems a little surly. place gets overrun with kids for a couple of hours on school days. the kids are mostly cool but they can be a little loud and a little distracting. but mostly I'm happy to see kids sharing spaces with adults--it's good for everyone.

seems pretty dog-friendly. please bus your own table - there is a tray for pete's sake, and these women aren't your mothers. 

further,
I haven't had any problem with unfriendly service. these women work day in & out so I am not horrified when they treat me as another anonymous customer. yes, it knocks off a star, but it doesn't make for a BAD experience. for what it's worth, taking a moment to say "how are you?" might get them on your side. it also helps to be a regular customer.
author: Ariel G.

description:
A place to go when Dolores Park Cafe and Mission Beach and Tartine and every other pricier place in the hood is overstuffed with strollers seeking refueling after a  session on the new Bellagio-sponsored play experience in what was formerly known as Dolores Park.

Meaning it's unpretentious, there's always seats, it feels big and chill, and the BLTs are good.
author: Mandy H.

description:
No matter what pastries are served or how cute this place is...and it is....the woman I met today behind the counter HATES HER LIFE. 
This was my first and last visit to Maxfield's. 
No eye contact whatsoever. Did not even ask what I wanted. Just walked up to me after tidying and pretending I was invisible for a bit and stared at me. 

Sadly, this place has a great atmosphere and is being run by Debbie Downer. 
My coffee was great.
author: Melody M.

description:
It is a great stop to read and write or just to meet a friend. Lovely big windows that allow so much brightness in. Good selection of drinks and a decent food selection of snacks.

I have to agree with previous posters I do find the superiority complex exuded by the main owner/worker very jarring. It put me in a bad mood, I don't like that anyone thinks they can behave to someone like that. It's just not on.

The other lady was very pleasant and even brought my coffee to me as the other guy decided not to call out that it was ready and it was left there for several minutes. He basically picks and chooses who he will be nice to, no consistency and I am too old in the tooth to play those peer pressure games of trying to be friends with the cool kid.

Anyhow I would return again as it is a great spot. Coffee is good. Wifi is fast. Right beside a laundromat, Dolores park and near public transport.
author: Annie L.

description:
Coffee: not my favorite "cup-o'-coffee"
Service: pleasant enough

As I sit here writing this review on my Mac, there are 11 others in the cafe, also typing away on their Macs. Talk about being part of the mainstream here. It must be the free wi-fi and the relaxing atmosphere. It's a sweet little corner cafe, light and bright.
author: Heidi H.

description: The people working here are rude as hell. I've worked around the corner for years and I really do love their apple cider, but these two ladies who run the joint have completely ruined any chance of me stepping foot in here again. Last week my boyfriend and I went in to grab a drink and get a bit of work done. I went up and ordered, got my drink, and sat back down. Then I realized I needed the wifi password so I went back up to ask for it and the lady said, "Is that man with you going to order anything? I can't give you the password if he's just sitting there." WOW. He was still getting settled and hadn't had time to get up to order yet.... Talk about not caring about your community. I've had a few other rude encounters with them before, but this is the most recent. Ugh. I want to like Maxfield's so much but they make it difficult.
author: Gabby T.

description:
convenient location, menu isn't too pricey, decent food/drink, and relatively spacey inside.
cool mix of characters: people catching up with friends, and also people catching up with work (laptops, books, etc). 
locals and tourists alike mingle in the peaceful ambiance here, where classics play on the radio for a lowkey vibe. I'm writing this review as I creep on customers head-bobbing along to Hotel California & Lennon's Imagine.
yes, the staff isn't the friendliest, but there are lots of outlets and free wifi for studying. 

warning: cash only, but they do have an ATM
author: Tuwie N.

description: Chai latte tastes super weird, bagel sandwich fell apart when I tried to eat it and the lady yelled at me when she got my order wrong. Too bad, this place looked promising.
author: Maddie R.

description:
When working at home has devolved into a loop of refreshing facebook every 10 minutes and doing unnecessary housecleaning or snacking, Maxfield's is a great place to go to get sh*t done.  Free wi-fi, plenty of plugs, decent tea selection, and lots of other people quietly working, providing the perfect level of judgement to keep me focused on finishing my work and off of shopping sites. 

Cash only. The music is spot on for working, although the tables are a little close, so it's pretty hard not to overhear your neighbor.  Bring headphones if you don't want to get all up in their business.
author: Lynn M.

description:
Good coffee, great atmosphere. I mostly spend my time at cafes working from a laptop, and Maxfield's is the place I go to most in the Mission.

The WiFi is reliable, it's easy to find outlets, and the coffee is pretty decent. Is only a couple blocks away from Dolores Park (and Bi Rite Ice Cream!) or the 16th & Mission BART station. It's open decently late (9pm as of 1/7/2013) and the staff is friendly.

EDIT: Whoa, what's with the negative comments about the staff and service? They've always seemed pleasant enough to me.
author: Al S.

description: I had a two day training thing I had to go to for work and I was still a little sick from the cold I was battling all week and needed much more coffee to make my morning manageable, found this place a block from the training site. Ordered an almond milk latte, the espresso is a bit thin, and my almond milk was a bit over steamed......but at least they were NICE unlike a score of other places in the Mission where being a barista gives people the "right" to give you a huge serving of attitude with your coffee, so bravo to you guys for being normal.
author: Bertamus R.

description:
I stopped in for a quick iced coffee after an afternoon at Dolores. The lady behind the counter was very pleasant. The coffee was tasty and did the job. I hung out on a couch for a few minutes before we left to catch a train.  

A nice coffee shop full of talkative people. I really like the huge walls and vaulted ceiling. Very comfortable.
author: Jordan P.

description:
Getting a job in order to relocate to San Francisco is the easy part. The tough part... finding housing. My weekend of sublet hunting, while looking for a temp place, finishing up my old job, and trying to pack and move, brought me here on a recommendation from someone whose place I'd just viewed.

I owe them a lot of gratitude for them letting me sit here for hours, obnoxiously on my phone and laptop, taking up valuable space as I scoured craigslist and made phone calls in the search for my perfect place. Did I mention free wifi and outlets!? All I had to do was buy one measly, inexpensive large chai and the staff, who were friendly when I ordered, didn't bother me at all.

Cash only, but since the beverages are inexpensive this wasn't a bit deal. I ended up not taking that sublet but think fondly on that visit due to the introduction to an internet freak's coffee house dream.
author: Denise B.

description: Maxfield's is place of standard fare with a name that boasts of great promise. It's nothing fancy, just straight up food and beverages at low to decent prices. The space is a little grungy from being worn in and the service is terse. I like that it's quick and easy, but there is nothng that stands out and it's certainly not a place I look forward to going. Just a place you happen to stop in for its convienence. The coffee's alright. There's a good amount of seating indoor and outdoor. The biggest plus is the free wifi.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I'm sitting here now facing the wall where there's a small sign that says: "if you are going to use our free wireless network access for an extended period of time, please remember to continue making purchases...."

I think that's totally fair. I use to spend hours at places like these, surfing the net...I buy stuff, but others just take up space. Bravo.

I'm here for one reason alone. I found parking at the Mission Dolores area. It must be a miracle.

The park across the street, the Mission behind us, it is no wonder it's been difficult for non-city people like me to ever hang out here. It's crowded, some seats along the walls, some small love seats, tables in a room with high ceiling. It's definitely a reason  why people would like to to sip their coffee, drink their tea and eat their food, while surfing the net.

It's a cool neighborhood cafe.
author: Reyz A.

description: Lady behind the counter was rude, cheap, and inhospitable when I asked about wifi service immediately after I paid for a drink. I had not even received my drink yet. I live in the neighborhood, and have been several times before, but I will never go back again.
author: C. H.

description:
I like this place. Decent coffee. Friendly staff. Power outlets. Good internet speeds.

http://www.speedtest.net/result/2767047287.png
(If Image doesn't last - 12mbps download, 2 mbps upload)
author: Jason H.

description:
Everything was alright with this place. It doesn't really stand out in my eyes. Coffee is a bit weak. I actually got sleepy while sipping my coffee. Outdoor seating is comfy, especially under the tree, although you'll get tree stuff falling on you all the time. Still much better than the indoor seating because it gets really hot inside, and KL said it smells like BBQ chicken. And it's full of apple snobs. I think KL and I are the only ones with dell laptops there. I didn't get a friendly vibe from the baristas. So, minus a star there.

Overall, the free wifi + outdoor seating + dogs= 3 stars.
author: Ari C.

description:
If you order a medium latte to drink inside Maxfield's, the size of the mug they give you is no different than that of their large. As one of the baristas told me, the size is a secret discount for the regulars who come in here all the time. Their chai tea is a perfect blend of sweet and spicy unlike other cafes in San Francisco where the chai is too much of either flavor.

Maxfield's is located in one of the best neighborhoods of San Francisco. The area is peaceful but the cafe is a perfect midpoint to where you have to get going. Valencia Street, Dolores Park and Church Street Muni are all a couple of blocks away. I also want to stress the word 'quiet.' It is extremely nice to sit outside and have the trees on Dolores Street be my focal point instead of the hoards of passersby on other streets.
author: Chris G.

description:
My plan was to come to Maxfield's on a particular day of the week, every week, to get serious writing done.  The plan did not work.  I did it twice--two weeks in a row, actually--but I haven't been back since.  That's a bummer.  The plan for the other particular day of the week is working out a little bit better, and I think that's because the other location* is a place nearer and dearer to my heart, although that's not technically true because my heart (and my entire body) reside only about a mile from Maxfield's while the other location is way out by Ocean Beach.  It just goes to show that the best laid--I know, I know; it doesn't help one's creativity to needlessly and carelessly quote quoted quotes.

The food is all right.  The people who work here could be friendlier, but then so could the clientele.  This seems to be a hotbed for people looking for jobs.  The last time I was here, I eavesdropped on three separate job-interview conversations.  One guy had already been offered a job, and he seemed to be holding out for more money.  After that conversation ended, I listened to him explain to his brother that he had been looking for a job for three months and that he was terrified that the place would balk at his hard bargain.  I have all kinds of opinions about that, both positive and negative, but I was impressed by the guy's confident wheeling and dealing; there wasn't a smidgen of doubt in the guy's voice.

I'm going to try again, but don't count on it working out.

*It's not that I'm paranoid, but consider my slight mysteriousness an impotent rebellion against the constant need to broadcast where one is and what one is doing at all times.  Honestly, most people don't care.
author: John S.

description:
The staff are a total turn-off, and the coffee quality is terrible. They go so far as to give you one napkin at a time from behind the counter. I only used to go there because it was one of the only internet cafes in the area open later.

Cheap about everything and a great example of how not to run and staff such a business.
author: G F.

description:
This is my neighborhood internet cafe of choice. However, if I want amazing coffee, then I head down to Ritual or Four Barrel on Valencia St.

Overall Maxfield's is a nice low-key coffee shop/cafe with ample seating options and plug outlets available. It's a great space to hunker down, set up shop, and get stuff done. 

Downsides: cash only and sometimes the barista sings loudly to annoying music (sorry).
author: becca j.

description: Great location near the park and far enough away from any nearby busy corridors. I've had both good sandwiches and bad pastries here, so I can't say the food options are reliable but the space is large and comfortable and it doesn't ever seem too busy or crowded. Some of the chairs aren't very comfortable but maybe it's on purpose to discourage camping out too long for free wifi...
author: Alex A.

description: Great place to study when you're not being harassed by the baristas. One of the ladies that worked there approached our table asking one of our friends if she was going to order anything because if not she was going to charge her $1 for every 10 minutes. This is even after 5 of us already purchased drinks. So 5 minutes later the same lady approaches the one of our friends and straight up tells her she has to leave, not knowing that she had a cup of tea in her hand. My friend showed her the cup and she said 'sorry' and left us alone. Quite possibly the rudest encounter ive had in this otherwise friendly city. The positives were that they had ample plugs for laptops and a variety of drinks to choose from (even had Thai iced tea). But the service tanked this place to the tune of 1 star.
author: Fernan C.

description:
FOOD:
1.) choc croissant - mmm... 


SERVICE:
bustley sunday morning. Free wifi! yay! 


ATMOSPHERE:
Cute, I like it. Fits the Mission. Few out door tables. Number of ppl working on their laptops, doing their own thing, readin the paper. Some dogs chillen outside while their owners sip on coffee n enjoy what precedes a lazy Sunday. 1106
author: Angela L.

description:
Good coffee, beer, wine, muffins, bagels with various spreads, sandwhiches, etc.  Bigger than average cafe, with large windows in the front for reading the paper but still plenty of spots to sit without sunlight hitting your laptop.  Bonus for good location - close to dolores park and the mission, but not to hard to find street parking if you got one of them cars.

3/5 coffee
4/5 atmosphere
4/5 food
4/5 service
3/5 value

Free wireless - http://www.yelp.com/list_details?userid=mkQ-J4uMULsJvc9V8gMENw&list_id=xJ_tC-4_YAdDCurRxaQBNw
author: chad n.

description:
I really wanted to like this place given it's a block away from my apartment.  Unfortunately, it's run by a bunch of sociopaths. 

You will read similar stories in other reviews.  We entered with our year old son one early morning.  As we waited for our order, he approached one of the PCs there and played with the mouse.  The barista - who btw didn't sing (see other reviews) - started screaming repeatedly: "Sir! Get your kid off of the computer!".  I was standing right behind my son, and it was clear I'm watching him and won't let him damage anything.  Moreover, the mouse in question was a 2 button, non-optical one, so it's worth maybe $3.  I have never been screamed at like that.  Even a polite request would have been weird given the situation, so such screams were completely uncalled for.  We took our stuff to go and left.

The place is just not hospitable. There are signs everywhere warning customers repeated purchases are expected if one is to use the "free" wifi (as if it's such a unique offering).  They don't have a baby high chair and tables were left dirty long after customers left.  And it's cash only, which I find annoying.

So aside from service, the food: 2 mediocre cappuccinos and airplane like cold, gummy bagels.  Pretty miserable, if pretty cheap.

If these guys are banking on a Soup Nazi like attitude, the least they could do is offer quality products.  I know many of you don't have kids and won't care about our experience with the baby, but really, both service and food are bad.

Bottom line is that in a neighborhood with so many other choices, there's zero reason to go to Maxfields.
author: J.G S.

description: This has pretty much everything you want out of a coffee shop: ample seating, interesting (but not disruptive) clientele, copious caffeine options, and free WiFi.  The food options are good, but not mind-blowing (I'm kind of a foodie snob. I own it.), so while it was definitely a great and convenient option, I didn't have an oh-my-god taste bud experience.  that said, I didn't have the entire menu, so that judgment is somewhat skewed.
author: Amber G.

description:
Shut up, shut up, shut UP ALREADY!!!

I can't believe there are so many reviews from people complaining they couldn't use the WiFi without purchasing something (HELLO, you are taking up a seat that a paying customer could occupy) and only a couple of mentions of the INCREDIBLY ANNOYING Barista who not only sings along to the music (I don't have a trouble with the pop he plays), but at the top of his lungs. Brace yourself when Madonna comes on, and bring your earplugs. 

My husband and I come here because of the reliable WiFi, the airy atmosphere, and the decent food. It's nice to have the flexibility to come in the morning for a breakfast bagel, in the afternoon for a sandwich, or in the early evening for a beer. The food is always fine, and cheaper than in a place like Cafe XO. 

But seriously, the Barista and his incessant singing ruin it for me. If he would just STFU I'd give Maxfield's five stars. How can the owners not realize his "perfomances" are off-putting to customers?
author: Carole M.

description:
Other yelpers are right on about the service. The guy working the counter, perhaps the son of the owner, isn't the most personable in the world. Barely audible. Thank you isn't part of his vocabulary. I felt lucky to get an explanation as to why I was charged $0.50 extra for my sandwich. What's that? Because I wanted tomatoes on my sandwich? Not cool on so many levels.

A solid two star yelp took a detour when I got my sandwich. Wow. Turkey with cranberry and apple slices packed on wheat bread. This was an excellent sandwich, and even with the tomato surcharge, felt like a deal for six bucks. 

Americano on the way out was solid as well.

Two stars for the not so friendly guy taking my money. Four stars for the awesome sandwich made by the not so friendly guy's mom (I think). Let's go with three stars for the yelp win.
author: Jason B.

description:
Ever since SF has upped it's coffee game it's hard to go back to coffee shops like these that were popular when Pearl Jam was. This place brings back 1993 in a hard way with grafitti in the bathroom and on various chairs and tables.

If you are a techie though, you suck it up and hang out here because for some reason some of the best hackers in the world cannot tell the difference between good and bad coffee.
author: Jim B.

description: Not your friendly neighborhood coffee place. This morning the only guy that was working there was scary mean. He was an angry man. I walked in carrying my preschool age son who couldn't make it home in time to go "number 1" and I asked kindly if he could use the bathroom. He was obviously not happy and when I turned the corner, he yelled at me in an angry man's voice to get the key.  In Europe (and I am American) they understand that we are human beings and have to use the bathrooms but here it seems if you are out in public we would rather you pee on the street or in your pants. Look I hate to clean bathrooms too but then get another job if you hate working with humans. I would have purchased something even though I didn't need anything because that is what city business expect to use their bathrooms but I didn't have my wallet. Ran out! So...really mean angry man, he is a toddler, we are clean, and NOW I will never be a customer in the future.
author: Tiffany M.

description: Great place to grab something to eat and a coffee. The place is spacious with great seating and free wifi. The shop now accepts credit cards.
author: Ana C.

description:
Free WiFi....check
Ample outlets to plug in laptops to access said WiFi...check
Reasonably priced coffee... check
Great bagel/egg/cheese breakfast sandwich...check

I mean really, what more is there to want from a coffee shop? The atmosphere is open and airy and the location is a few steps away from Dolores Park. 2 thumps up (and 4 stars) for Maxfields!
author: Kelly N.

description:
A lot of cafes around this area cover up their plugs on purpose, Maxfield doesn't. There's a lit of seating, plenty of plugs, and decent food. Great place to get some work done on the laptop.

After you're done, head out to Dolores park 2 blocks away.
author: James B.

description:
The place has style and a healthy sense of irony. The coffee's forgettable except that it doesn't hold back on the establishment's eponymous ingredient. I like most of the music they play. Added bonuses include a fun staff, friendly (well-caffeinated) customers, and some of the best men's room graffiti I've ever seen. Sometimes I wish this one dude who's on at night didn't sing his absolute loudest, but then I suppose that's my fault for reading in his workplace.

If someone follows this up with confirmation that the women's room graffiti meets the high standard of the men's room, I'll up this review to five stars.

*In my patriarchal daze I neglected to note that the one restroom is unisex, and therefore all comers may view the fine graffiti. Also, the aforementioned singer wrote back and was a good sport about it. Ergo, five stars. Sweet.
author: James D.

description:
My go-to spot in my hood for a quick breakfast.  Their breakfast croissants are absolutely amazing, though I've yet to put my finger on exactly what makes it so good compared to other places.  In any case, it never disappoints.  The fresh squeezed orange juice, though expensive, is also great. 

I'm no coffee expert so I can't add much of value in this department but it does the trick for me.  

The decor it nothing special but it feels comfy and cozy to me. 

In response to people complaining about the sign requesting patrons to make purchases if their going to use the "wi-fi", I can't see how this isn't a fair.  I consider this an unwritten rule anywhere I go and use wifi.  I guess some people feel entitled to getting things for free...
author: John H.

description:
I've lived near Dolores park and found that I usually end up at Maxfield's on my work from home day or if I need to get some breakfast (My favorite -- breakfast bagel with sausage and cheddar).  

Free wifi, ample electric plugs, cash only, and reasonably quiet.  

The service is ok -- despite going a couple times a week for 4-5 months, and seeing the same three baristas, I don't really feel connected.  

For me, I guess location wins (I've gone to morning due, cafe petra, and cafe du soliel and almost always end up just going to Maxfield's instead).
author: Jonathan H.

description:
Maxfield is about 100 yards from my apartment, and it's kind of great. They've been making me breakfast bagels several days a week for years now and their bagels are definitely among the best in the area. It's also a great place to hang out and work on your laptop or read the paper on Saturday morning.  I can't really speak for the coffee, but they have excellent fresh-squeezed orange juice. 

Also: Stephen the singing barista and his excellent music selections. Just yes.
author: Alice N.

description:
This is more like a 3.5-3.8 star place, but I'm in a happy mood so I'm just giving it a full 4 stars.

I am currently obsessed with Maxfields' sandwiches. No idea why. I think it's the bacon they use. The BLT and club are what I usually get and I'm always full and happy afterwards (for lunch). Prices are good and the service is quick and nice. I like how there's ample seating. We usually come here to chill while we wait for our laundry next door.

Basically, when I feel like a simple, well-priced sandwich, I come to Maxfields.
author: Angela H.

description:
I used to like Maxfield's for its spacious interior, outdoor seating, reliable wi-fi, and slew of outlets, ready to be plugged away by workaholics on their laptops. Aside from being a great place to work, there are couches and outdoor seating perfect for a chat or board game with a friend. It's proximity to Dolores Park and Bi-Rite Creamery makes it a great place to spend a day working, then playing.

However, I had an experience that will never send me there again.

Yesterday, a friend and I went their to work on our laptops. Immediately, he bought an iced coffee while I proceeded to work. Soon after we arrived, a woman who I presume is the owner approached me and asserted that if I were to use her wi-fi, I should purchase a drink.

I agree. Normally, I always buy a drink and some snacks whenever I'm at a cafe and I have plenty of times before at Maxfield's. But I had a big breakfast and a cup of water so I wasn't in the mood at that time to get anything. And I also did not appreciate the fact that she applying a lot of pressure for me to do so.

A few minutes later, she called for my attention again. "Excuse me, are you going to get a drink? Because if you're not I'm going to have to charge you for every minute you use the wi-fi."

Let's discuss this. I think its the ethical thing to purchase something if you were to use their space and Internet. However, I don't think it's a good business practice to regulate your whole store, going from person to person to make sure they purchase something.

Does that create an inviting space? Will it make the customers want to come back again, even if they do purchase something at that time? Probably not.

This is what I told her and I left. As people increasing use cafes as a space to study and work away from home as I do, it's important and courteous to support the business who offer their space and wireless. I do and I probably would've in that situation if she approached in a less demanding and brash fashion.

I understand her frustration and her point of view, but if she continues that approach I feel like it won't be an enjoyable space for either the cafe's owner or its patrons.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Maxfield's is my corner coffee shop.  It's not bad, but it's also not great.  I too would give 2.5 starts, but I'm rounding down to match those who rounded up.  

Here's the scoop...

COFFEE: It's ain't Blue Bottle, It ain't Ritual, but it's also not that swill they serve at the office.

SCENE: Lots of folks on laptops.  Very few folks talking to each other.  Lots of tourists coming over from Mission Dolores.  I really miss Reverie in Cole Valley, where strangers were always starting conversations with each other, creating a real sense of community.

DECOR: Light and airy, with the requisite rotating local art on the walls.  A variety of seating options: inside, outside, and uncomfortable couches.

SERVICE: I've gone to Maxfield's weekly and ordered a non-fat cappuccino eac time.  They've never once said "can I get you the regular?"  That being said, the service isn't "bad," it's just not "great."

FOOD: The breakfast bagels are tasty.  Haven't tried anything else.
author: David G.

description:
OK, I reviewed this place before and took off two stars for the singing barista who sang much too loudly and melodramatically, plus has a terrible need to always play music by Garbage/Shirley Manson.  

The otherwise hard working and efficient fellow has toned down the theatrics to an acceptable level, so I am adding a star as encouragement. 

Max Fields is much more inviting and can have its cake an eat it, too -- a singing barista that is no longer repellent.  Just, uh, play less Shirley Manson/Garbage, please.
author: Paul S.

description:
Movie in the park.  Beetlejuice.  Needed munchies.  Accidentally happened upon Maxfield's.

Somehow, at that moment, the one thing missing from my life was a PB & J sandwich.  The nice woman at the counter fixed me up a mean PB & J (although by the way she looked at me and asked me three times what I wanted - it might have been the first time she had heard of such a thing).    BFF, Annalise ordered some kind of veggie wrap thing that looked Ah-may-zing.

My conclusion:  If you're going to see a movie in the park and want a quick bite, this place is all you could want and more.
author: Mariko H.

description: Got hot apple cider with a cinnamon stick :) needed a little extra spice, (which they had on hand,) but great :) very autumny. My boyfriend got a blended mocha. Best one he's ever had. A bit pricey and the older woman seemed a little tense, but worth the trip. Lots of baked goods. Very cute atmosphere as well.
author: Stefanie G.

description:
Positives: Beautiful location, generally very nice staff. 

Negatives: Gets extremely crowded on the weekends with the kind of people who sit at tables for hours with their computers while ordering nothing.  And while we're on the subject, let's talk about the coffee, since that's (implicitly) part of their name.  In brief, it sucks. It tastes like hot water. You don't have to be a "coffee snob" (as one other reviewer put it) to notice that the "coffee" here has no coffee flavor whatsoever.
author: Mike M.

description:
I enjoy this place because I can get an easy iced mocha w/ soy, or whatever that tastes reasonably decent. I like that I can rely on the wi-fi being up and moving swiftly, as I'm always with laptop in tow.

Someone said the music could be loud... I agree, and not to be mean, because I really like the guys that work there -- but one guy LOVES to belt out the tunes... LOUDLY. So, if you're bothered by someone laying their own vocals on top of a blaring CD track, I wouldn't go there during the early part of the day. Also, if you hate country music, you may be turned off by the lady's music selection. But if you're like me and can go with the flow (thanks to a great pair of headphones), then this place is A-OK.
author: Josh M.

description:
Some of the people behind the counter are psychopaths. I kept going back to give them a chance, though, because I want local places to succeed. But I can't handle the rudeness anymore. And thankfully, I have better options on Valencia now, like Borderlands and The Blue Fig.

Other than the customer-hating service, they do have reliable wifi, mediocre cafe food and drinks (nothing special), sunny room with large windows, a few tables and chairs on the sidewalk. But I recommend you skip this place and go to The Blue Fig. They've got just as many sunny tables and good coffee, AND they are so nice to their customers.
author: Kelly R.

description: This is one of my favorite cafe's in San Francisco. It's near Dolores Park, but far enough away that it's not always packed. The staff is friendly and the prices are cheap. The coffee is strong, and it's comfy to sit and work for a bit of time.
author: Aaron H.

description:
Maxfield's, no complaints on the quality of food. You are about a block away and walking to you is easy but the things I don't like are that

a) The floor is never cleaned
b) The signs everywhere asking people to keep on buying to use the internet. 

I don't use the internet here, but I expect to be able to stay for awhile after I finish my food without having to feel guilty about using the web. That's just me though.
author: Alexia R.

description: Meh...   Order a soy latte and it's on the same level as Starbucks in terms of quality.  It's got nuttin' on Blue Bottle Coffee!  Coffee is very WEAK!!!  DH thinks it's b/c of the coffee bean they're using and NOT b/c of the preparation.  The ONLY reason my husband and I went is b/c of the clever store name.  We will NOT be coming back here again!  Next time we're in the area, we'll aim for either 1) Samovar or (if we REALLY want coffee...) STARBUCKS!!!  At least we'll get rewards for it!  :(
author: Joanna R.

description: There is nothing worse than walking into a coffee shop in the A.M. to have your cup of coffee and you ask the clerk, "How are you doing today?" and he replies, "Ugh I just wanna go home." Not very positive vibes in the morning. I don't know about any of you but I am really sensitive to people's energies.
author: Kayla G.

description:
I first came here last Tuesday, following a 3 hour stunt at the DMV, and a 1 hour muni bus trip with a transfer, during rush hour.  The agoraphobic in me needed a sanctuary to seek some peace and quiet, and most of all, a healthy dose of personal space.  Getting off one stop ahead of my destination, I walked past by Maxfield's -- merely a block from my house, I've seen this place multiple times but never went in, and since there were only 3 people in there, I snuck in and ordered a house coffee and a hummus sandwhich, grabbed a table and started to read my media analysis report.

a sense of calm soon came over. the coffee house has a high ceiling and plenty of sunshine (unlike cafe petra down the street which to me resembles a speakeasy that serves coffee, a different type of vibe, and to be sure, not necessary bad.) the Sunlight addict in me is satiated, much like a plant in a greenhouse.

The coffee was strong and resilient. the hummus sandwich satisfying. I stayed for a bit and made sure to come back. as I was leaving, the coffee dude thanked me for visiting. He's not my boyfriend, but i felt like i just got a hug. 

Today, I came back to this coffee house, somewhat broken and curled at the edge, and again, my coffee house (yes, i have a feeling that this will be my house from this point on) takes me in for a much needed retreat into urban anonymity.  My iced soy latte was made quickly, and I found a table next to a lanky & cute boy who is no-doubt also searching for his own oasis of privacy. We're stealing glances at each other right now, or at least i'm flattering myself and thinking he is, while I am. :) 

Thank you Maxfield's for your deliberately small tables that allows the socially awkward laptop addicted dorks like me to escape the constant pressure to engage proactively with fellow life-escapees.  and thanks for the not so serious coffee, the just slightly ugly clientele, and artworks that doesn't pretend to be more than what it is -- why that mickey mouse shaped skull and bones pretty much matches how i feel on the inside today. 

You Not-cool-enough-for-Coffee-Bar Customer,
Me
author: Lynn T.

description:
Maxfield's boasts super strong coffee on a sign in the window, but let me just tell you, it's more like rocket fuel.  If you're a big coffee drinker, you may not notice the caffeine, but I don't drink coffee very often and after one small cup of this stuff I'm bouncing off the walls.  I can't decide if this is a good thing or bad thing about Maxfield's, but I guess since they warn you I can't hold it against them.

I was VERY pleasantly surprised to see a Veggie Bagel on the menu that includes all of my favorite ingredients for a breakfast bagel - cc, cucumber, tomato, sprouts, red onion.  The bagels are so so, and they don't overload on the cc, which is nice.  They keep the focus on the veggies.  They'll serve it open-faced if you dine in, which makes for a cleaner eating experience and obviously twice the veggies... it's pretty amazing, I must say.

The only thing that I don't like about Maxfield's is the lack of napkins... they'll give you one with your food, but no other napkins to be found - !?

I appreciate Maxfield's very much and am lucky to live within a few blocks of this coffee/veggie bagel deliciousness.
author: Alice H.

description:
A stone's throw from Dolores Park, FREE INTERNETS...cookies & milk for $2.50.

The barista dude wasn't too friendly, though. Matter of fact...I'm not sure he said one word to me or anybody else who has come to order since.

At least I can review the place while I'm sitting inside of it.
Yea, that merits 3 stars.
author: matt m.

description:
After a solid day of home improvements on Saturday, I received a call from some friends who were heading to Dolores Park for the afternoon. I'd been wanting to do that since I moved here, ya know, just hang in the park and people and doggie watch, but just hadn't found the time yet, so Sunday afternoon sounded swell.

I then left my pad and started heading down Dolores and spotted this place.
