Hmmm, I hadn't been craving any caffeine-like substances, but hmmm, this place looks kinda cool, oh, okay, why not, what's a little caffeine. I then headed in and it was packed. Groups chatting over coffee, people reading, people actively typing away on their laptops and one guy clearly in an IM chat and laughing, but trying not to. It was a cute scene for a Sunday afternoon.

I then walked up to the counter and ordered my iced tea. Now I can't say that the woman was all that friendly, but she was by no means rude, just sort of indifferent which was kind of a bummer, since nothing pairs better with a caffeine drink then a little smile. As for the iced tea, it hit the spot and made for a refreshing addition to my Dolores Park Sunday. Not sure that I would rush back here again, but if I ever find myself heading to the park via Dolores, I might give them another go in the hopes that their face muscles are looking up that day :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
Chill place for Coffee and whatever

Just came here for the first time today.  The totally rainy day made Maxfield's House of Caffeine seem extra inviting.  My friends chose this place to get together for an art collaboration.  The seating is very conducive to getting a few friends together for a quick coffee, or arriving solo to type away on our Macbook (or non Mac :-)  Upon arrival, you will probably find everybody glancing down to their sketches, laptops, or other creative things.  It seems like the coffee served is expressly for fueling your creative mind. 

The coffee is was just good.  Served in a tall mug to-stay, or paper cup to go, it hit the spot.  I didn't try any of the espresso drinks, but my friends have said that they are also good.

If I lived in the area, this place might be a regular of mine.  

Solid 3-Stars!

Also, Art approves.
author: Shea G.

description:
This is a 5star place for sitting down and working on your laptop.  There is plenty of seating, a good wifi connection, great sandwiches, decent coffee, outlets, and best of all, an all glass front that lets you view beautiful Dolores Street  while you site and plug away.  I'm no coffee snob, so that doesnt really factor into the rating.  They pour it from a premade batch that in one of those insulated dispensers, so its nothing fancy, but they have beer and great freshly made sandwiches and its a great location and vibe.

Also, its in the mission, so cash only
author: Mathias G.

description:
Vietnamese Ice Coffee in the Mission Dolores area?????!!?!?!!?

Free Wi-Fi!??!?!?!!?

This place is the t*ts.
author: David C.

description: Decent, albeit slightly dirty place. However the free wifi, location and large space makes this place a decent place to frequent.
author: Charlie B.

description:
After a long afternoon spent jumping around the inside of a bouncy castle at a friend's birthday party in Delores Park, I was in need of a pick-me-up (seriously, how do little kids do this stuff for hours on end? it's tiring!) The sun had gone down & that cool evening wind was whipping through the park.

On the way to the car, we dropped into Maxfield's to warm our hands & hearts. The barista had just put the Arcade Fire on, so we ordered hot beverages, sat down & recharged. By the time the album was over with, we were on our way.

I'm of the opinion that Delores St is THE best street in SF, hands down. Maxfield's is clean, quiet & warm. The right kind of low key. The kind of low key that befits such an amazing street. I'd love to call Maxfield's my local coffee shop one day (I should be so lucky).

As an aside, there's amazing graffiiti on the bathroom walls.
author: Pete J.

description:
The sun is shifting.  

We were comfortable in the shade right next to the place, but now the heat is unbearable, for me and the comp.  Luckily they have another table across the sidewalk...right next to the street...but under a tree - it affords another, probably, half an hour?  It's too hot to go inside, so when the sun hits again, I think it'll be time to move on.

Iced coffee was fine, and as I said, seating was cool.  Scenery is okay, but not enough people to really people-watch...Ritual was much much better for that.
author: Kerrie L.

description:
"House of Caffeine," reads their sign.
Now this is MY kind of place.  Gimme my CAFFEINE!
 
Nice and cozy interior - - and really cool outdoor space.  Parking is not that difficult, or at least, it wasn't for me today.
Coffee is OK --  their baked goods are pretty decent, though we only tried two things.
 
Great place for a first date, or just to hang out w/ one or 2 people for a warm afternoon in San Francisco.  
Service is also friendly.  
 
I noticed a laundromat next door - - drop your laundry in and come next door to drink some coffee?
 
Also - they have beer on tap - - Fat Tire, amongst 3 or 4 others.
 
That said - - coffee quality is not as good as, say, Blue Bottle or even S-bucks, Peet's..... but it's still pretty decent, with good prices - and better atmosphere than other coffee joints.
 
They also seem to make interesting sandwiches, which I'll try on my next visit.
author: Grace K.

description:
If you have to get stuck writing your master's thesis on one of the most beautiful, sunshine-filled, gorgeous days we will have this summer and possibly EVA (not bitter), at least you can do it at an outside table at Maxfield's while watching oodles of happy people with their cute as pie pooches make their way to lovely dolores park to eat, drink, and soak up some rays with their friends (still not bitter).

Free wi-fi, good people watching, decent coffee, tons of outlets to plug into, and a good selection of comfy couch seating and outside tables.  Imagine the stars I would give this place if I wasn't bitter.
author: Laura H.

description:
It's all about the flashbacks.

I've only been here twice -- the first time was some months ago when I was unemployed, and the second is today when I am (un)fortunately (not un)employed.  

For months, whenever I biked by I felt bogged down by the weight of the $2 debt I owed the super friendly coffee slinger -- he paid for my PBR when my debit card refused to work at their inside ATM (it's a cash only establishment).  

Today I came clean, blurting out my unsolicited confession.  He refused to accept my repayment, at least directly, instead proposing that I purchase some of his buttons.  A barter of some sorts, a good deal overall and further evidence of his awesomeness. 

My bedraggled body likes the feel of this corner seat with the cusion, but mostly the music lifts my spirits and makes me laugh: old STP that I "reviewed" for the school paper in eighth grade; "What is Love?", which always floods my senses with warm memories of the gay '90s.  Nothing I would necessarily listen to or admit I listen to, but nostalgia is powerfully convincing.

Damn this recession ... bring back the love.
author: Patricia D.

description: A conveniently located alternative when the ever-popular Dolores Park Cafe (a.k.a. the dyke cafe) is too crowded to tolerate.  Very pleasant outdoor seating and lots of people watching opportunities.
author: Rick H.

description:
3 and a half stars?  Really?  I actually like this cafe, nevermind that Ritual Roasters is closer to me and has, admittedly, better coffee.  Here's why:  If I ever spend a significant time at a cafe or a coffee shop, it's to bring up my laptop and do a little bit of work while I nosh on something and have a sip of a latte.  

And I like the atmosphere - an earlier reviewer was making fun of the guys playing D&D - and yes, they were there when I was there as well, yelling VERY LOUDLY THAT YOU CAN'T TAP MANA WITH THAT CARD (Magic: The Gathering, anyone?)  But I actually LIKE that in a cafe.  No pretentiousness, just a variety of crazy-ass San Francisco folk all congregated in one place.  When I'm at RR, I feel weird for being chubby and not having a heroin addiction.  It does the job for me, and I'm totally okay with that.
author: Ernie H.

description:
Not Great, Not Bad, Just there.

I was in town Sunday and just needed a place to sit down and do some serious reading for school. I was in the area because the #2 reason for coming to the city from Santa Cruz is for the amazing burritos of my childhood. 

So we were heading to Doloras Park to read and drink some beer, but the fog was starting to roll on in, so we changed our minds mid stride nd headed in to Maxfields. I'd been there once previously a few years ago and had some soup, but that was really all I had remembered. The fact that I hadn't gone back again, despite being in the area so often probably meant that I did not like it much.  But we went in anyway, I had some tea and played table hot potatoes until finding something comfortable. (The tables are really just too low for the chairs, my back was dying) 

Eventually I ended up in a comfy chair at the from of the place and was able to get my readings done while the BF used their free wi-fi,and had next to no feelings about the coffee quality.

The guy that works there is pretty obnoxious. OK, so he does have pretty decent taste in music (although, what what the deal with aqua? I hadn't heard barbie girl since grade school) But he was on the phone often, and with such a loud voice it was hard to concentrate on anything else at all.

Overall, it's definitely not a destination place, but if you are standing across the street and want a nice indoor place, Maxfields isn't that bad.
author: Allyson S.

description:
The staff is awesome, they remember your usual order. Coffee is sooo delicious. It's just a block from Dolores Park, and yet you don't feel nuts and cramped like in the Dolores Park Cafe. Food is so-so, pastries are average, and the espresso drinks are hit or miss depending on who's working, but I love their brewed coffee, and the atmosphere is *perfect* for working on papers, writing, emailing, or other business. Bright light, quiet.

Oh, AND they have a functioning changing table, and a bathroom big enough to get a mom and a stroller and a baby into. A big plus.
author: Cate F.

description:
Used to meet a friend here to study Chem.
It's very "neighborhoody" in that EVERYONE that lives within 10 blocks seems to hang out here.

They allow dogs to come in, which is pretty cool, but parking is a nightmare in this area.
author: Lisa B.

description:
One of the best things about Maxfield's is their location.  It has a beautiful tree in the front and has plenty of indoor seating and a few tables outside.  They also have free wi-fi.  

I had a soy chai latte which was actually really good.  I hate it when places make it super sweet and syrupy.  This one was had a little spiciness to it that was just awesome goodness in my mouth.  I was definitely pleased with it.  It looked like other people were eating sandwiches here, but I knew I had to save my appetite for Ike's which is a few blocks from here.
author: MissJennifer L.

description:
really nice to sit outside this place and read a book. Its a shame they dont take credit card though.

they do nice vegan breads made out of assorted veganish stuff. Nice.
author: mike o.

description: It's a nice big space on a quiet block which I like but the service is terrible.  There is a  guy behind the counter who   always seems to be radiating some kind of disgruntled vibe and the lady behind the counter, possibly the owner, with the reddish brown hair who has no clue about customer service.  I went in today and asked for a half caf coffee with soy.  She filled it halfway with regular and put a splash of decaf in before saying"We ran out of decaf, you want me to fill it with regular?"  Actually no.  That's why I asked for  a half decaf because I don't want a whole cup of caffeinated coffee at that time in the afternoon.  So I said "No"  she then said very rudely  and looking pissed, " You don't want it?" since it was barely a little over half full, I said "how about a discount?"  She snapped "I don't give discounts!" and turned her back and walked away clearly stewing. The cashier  guy gave me my money back.  "some customer service" I said.  The guy looked me up and down and shrugged.  So you thought I should pay full price for a cup of coffee barely over half full because you ran out of decaff and are to lazy and disgruntled to make more? Kiss my ass.  I went to Muddy Waters on Valencia instead where the staff is super nice and always give everyone a smile.
author: S. G.

description:
It's sticky to the touch. And all I tried was coffee because everything else seemed to be the standard cafe fare. And I'm not even into that whole coffee & cafe scene.

What I like about this place is that:
a) the Batista complimented one of my tattoos
b) the space is pretty cool. and by pretty cool I mean not over stylized like many cafes are with the funky 90's chairs and "friends"-esque painted walls in some shade of god-awful red or purple. 
and
c) it's called Maxfield's House of Caffeine. Awesome.
author: Penelope C.

description:
i LOVE this place. 
When I moved to this neighborhood a few months ago I searched around for a coffee shop within walking distance to my home. A few places popped up but I chose Maxfield's because I liked the mixed reviews. It seems people either love it or hate it here. After coming here for over 3 months I am ready to write a review. 
Maxfieds is amazing. I come here in the morning to get an iced latte, soy lately. I come here before I go to the park to get iced tea with friends. I come here to meet friends and dates. I come here a lot. Why you might ask? simple, they are nice. Maxfields staff is what makes this place so special. Why others seem to complain about the staff members here who sing I love it. Individuality and loving life is what all people should be about. If you are singing at work i think you have those two qualities down and I like that. Plus hearing a rendition of Madonna's vogue at 8am never gets tiresome. All of the employees here are super friendly and my order always comes out fast... and correct. Two biggies some places fail on. 
All in all I am grateful to have such a unique, clean, friendly and speedy coffee place near my home. 
Maxfield's, you are the best, don't ever let anyone tell you otherwise.
author: Wes P.

description:
The food ain't that great but there really wasn't much more to not like about the place. It's literally 2 blocks away from Dolores Park so its quiet enough to get stuff done but active enough to people watch. The space is huge with full height windows so there's a ton of light helping with the "I hate that I have to be inside to do stuff but thank god I can see what's happening out there". 

I had their chicken sandwich which was basically a microwaved chicken breast on a chiabatta roll with some toppings. Mmm, chewy. They offer a full coffee selection (don't know anything about that) but they also have a selection of moderately priced beers and an assortment of canned/bottle drinks. Hot day = miller lite!

Topping it off, the place has free wifi and outlets available (granted, they're all clustered in a corner which could be difficult). There are a ton of seats/tables so space wasn't an issue.  

In the end, the place is great to do what you need to do.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
Fantastic place.  Great location, great side walk, great coffee, reasonably priced snacks/lunches, free wifi, and they serve beer.  So far, a five star rating.  Why do I give them only three?

One minor reason is the TV feeding headlines and ads.  Yeesh.  TV-B-GONE!

But the major reason is a particular hipster jerk that operate a few of the shifts.  I'll spare you the details of what I just observed.  Suffice it to say this guy's unnecessary passive-aggressive bullshit cost the cafe customers.  If I owned this joint I'd fire that guy.  If he owns any part of the place, he's a fool.
author: Brian C.

description: Not a bad place to go grab a quick coffee before beading over to Dolores Park for some chatting.  The nice thing about this place would be how they have soy milk on the side so you can add a bit to your coffee/tea free of charge and the fact that they have brown sugar.  :)  Downside, the cafe is cash only.
author: Anna V.

description:
Free WiFi                   Check
Ok coffee                   Check
Enough space          Check
Friendlyish staff        Check
People Watching      Kinda

It's somewhere between 2.5 and 3.5 so hey, 3 made perfect sense.

Times visited: 3
Time spent there: 5-10 mins (I'm a grab-n-go coffee drinker)
author: Rich S.

description:
Fuck this place. 

I met a client there recently, well more than an hour before they were supposed to close. I asked for a cup of regular decaf coffee (which isn't unreasonable considering it was a little before 8 p.m. on a Thursday night), but I was told, "Oh, sorry, we don't have any ready, and I don't want to brew a whole pot."

First, tough shit. I could see if you were about to lock up. But damn, in the next hour or so, how unlikely is it somebody else might want a cup of decaf? 

Second, even if you poured the whole pot out, so what? How much money did you really lose?

Third, points one and two are not my problem. You're a COFFEE shop. Coffee shops sell COFFEE, including decaf. At what point in your schedule should I be sensitive to your concepts of supply and demand?

Then, my client goes to sip his coffee and spits it right out! Seems the milk was completely spoiled. 

Real nice, Maxfield's.

On top of that, when we sat outside, it reeked of sewer system. No, this isn't Maxfield's fault since the smell came from outside the building, but it did serve as an appropriate metaphor for the experience.
author: Derek R.

description:
To me, this place is the platonic ideal of the coffee shop. I go there pretty much every weekend. Tasty breakfast bagels (my regular is the bacon and cheddar on sesame). Not too crowded. But I can't lie, the thing that first sold me on Maxfield's is the hand painted signage out front, and the big floor-to-ceiling windows on one side where light streams in and rakes across the tables. Plus, it's a block from Dolores Park.

The only way it could be better is if it had more board games. Scrabble, perhaps?
author: Andy S.

description: The most affordable coffee shop near Dolores park, with accessible outlets! Its truly an anomaly. They even have comfortable couches, which seem to be eschewed in most other coffee shops in town. The selection is not huge, but it has everything that matters. The sandwiches are affordable and yummy, and the service friendly. Its not the most visually appealing, but the windows let in a lot of light.
author: Carrisa P.

description:
This is going to be one of those reviews that is really more like a diary entry that you all get to read, because, well, I really need to keep a diary or write in a journal or WRITE THAT DAMN NOVEL, but instead I am a working hack who only has like two minutes to spew out a review before returning to the grind.  So here goes. 

Last night I had some time to kill before meeting a friend of mine at Samovar Tea Lounge (the Sanchez location), so I decided to go *read* at a cafe.  As I pondered my location for said reading I decided that as a single woman I should go to a cafe that has STRAIGHT men for a change.  I love the Castro, but WTF, CAN SOMEBODY PLEASE STARE AT MY BREASTS?!  (sorry) 

So I decided that I would go to Maxfield's.  I've never been to Maxfield's before and it was not too far from Samovar and it was close enough to the Mission Dolores area that I thought HEY perhaps there will be some hipster, writer/photographer with tight pants and a IPhone here that I can make eyes at over my book, The Historian, which is really not very good and which I only bought because it's about vampires and I LOOOOOVE me some good vampire lore (holla Ann Rice!). 

So I cruise into this joint and the first thing that goes wrong is that don't have any decaf. I know, I know, what a pussy you are thinking, and frankly, I think that too.  Every day that I fill my coffee cup up with decaf Major Dickenson's Roast I think, what a pussy you are Claire, why can't you just suck it up and drink the leaded shit?  Then, I have a dark chocolate cookie and have a panic attack, so really we're all better off.  Anyway, "out of decaf" leads me to some shitty ass tea, which you really can't fault them for cause it comes in a bag, etc etc. 

So I secure a spot in the corner and turn my attention to all of the guys in the room.  Ahem.  OK so have you ever seen something that you thought was not REAL, in the sense that it's like a scene in a movie. LIke that old lady in There's Something about Mary who is all brown with the crazy sagging tits and you are like, nooo that's a caricature, it's not real?  Well, I saw that shit here.  There were DEF no hot hipsters with iphones and scowls, there was a central table of out of this world dudes playing Dungeons and Dragons. 

Ohhhh Hell to the Motherf*&king yes there were!  And I could only stare and stare some more as they "cast spells" and quibbled amoungst themselves, completely unconcerned that others in the cafe might NOT care about the white or green spell card, or whatever it was they were saying in heated voices. I'm not EVEN going to describe what they looked like because, well, I don't want anyone to think I'm just a nerd haterater, cause I love me some nerds, but these guys really transcended the word NERD. 

So, um, I'll get back to you on the coffee, and needless to say I didn't strike it rich with the hot hipster, and, uh, this is the place to go if you wanna get in on some Hot D and D.
author: Claire C.

description:
I went here because it closed later than other coffee shops in the area. They have free wi-fi and a lot of electrical outlets. Also not a lot of people so it's quiet and easy to work. The prices are very reasonable. 

Cons: First off, it smelled really bad inside. I dunno if it was a customer or it came from outside, but it smelled like feces. Also, the iced soy chai latter I ordered was pretty bad, not the worst I ever had, but definitely no where near anything I would order again. The paintings on the walls are terrrrrrrible, incredibly bad amateur art. The rest of the decor was fine and enjoyable. Nice furniture. Lastly the music the barista put on was God awful! Top 40 radio bull crap from four years ago. Just unbearable, I had to use head phones with my own music.

I might come back again, but it won't be my favorite hang out.
author: Maciej M.

description:
I really really want to like this place more than I do.  It just doesn't work for me, but maybe it works for someone else....

Food? Good selection of sandwiches, desserts and they even have piroshkis, which I secretly crave.

WiFi? Definitely free with purchase.  And they even have a reasonably accessible power supply for laptops

Good place to work?  I want to say yes, but the ambiance just doesn't work for me.  The music can be distracting and I just don't feel comfy in the chairs and tables.

Verdict? I'll head over if I'm in the 'hood, but I think Morning Due or Dolores Park Cafe would be my preference.
author: Jane A.

description:
Yum Maxfield!
I feel so cozy there, you usually see a few people with kicked off shoes.
Steven is so funny, one of the best coffee personalities I have yet to meet in this beautiful city.
One block from Dolores Park.
Free Wireless (usually on, but has had the occasional problem).
The Avacado Sandwich ROX!
And they have a few brew on tap, and CIDAR! most smaller places don't have Cidar.

Good Stuff.
author: Kellie P.

description:
Originally lured in by the beautiful huge tree out front (which never ceases to make me happy) Maxfield's has become my favorite office/coffee house.  The wi-fi is solid and clean.  There are power outlets convenient to most tables and the atmosphere is really nice without being distracting.  Tea is cheap ($1.50 for Numi) and they have a wide variety of fresh organic snacks.  The "granola oat jacks" are AMAZING.  Service is super friendly, particularly as a regular.  I'm always cozy and productive here.

Yes, I know the coffee is mediocre.  So is the overwhelming majority of coffee around.  If I want coffee I go to Philz or Ritual.  If I want to pay $7 for some amazing tea I go to Samovar.  I come here to work about 2-5 days a week and for that purpose the place is perfect. $5 a day for work space including internet and a snack ain't bad and if I'm having a rough day I can always have a beer instead of tea.  It's a comfortable friendly and consistent place for me to get work done, thus 5 stars for the purpose.
author: Rich R.

description:
+punky D&D kids take over corner seats. 
+cushions, free and accessible water
+bohemia
-coffee not that great.
+pastries aight
author: Will T.

description:
Nice spot for a cuppa near Dolores Park. More relaxing than the DP Cafe.

Things to enjoy at Maxfields: espresso machine coffee, the light airy cosy atmosphere, pavement tables, free wifi, friendly service (haven't met the grumpy guy mentioned by someone below - I tend to go at the weekend)

Things not to enjoy at Maxfields: the drip coffee (see above)
author: Richard B.

description: Quality coffee house.  Friendly staff.  Good place to work while you sip on cafe au lait.  You'll need to buy something every couple of hours though if you want to work there all afternoon.
author: Michael G.

description:
Great coffee shop. Scrumptious sandwiches, free wi-fi and wine and beer for a sunny Sunday afternoon. 

One thing that sets this place apart from all the other coffee shops is the graffiti in the bathroom. From the politically charged to the sexually explicate, it provides entertainment for a good 10 mins while you take care of business. The notes are frequently updated to keep up with the changing times but i think "Jo.G on baker st has STDs" will reign supreme for years to come.  
Pure Classic.
author: Tak H.

description:
Perfectly likable cafe, and it's just a few doors away from my apartment, which is a huge plus.  Free wireless, warm inside, and art on the walls.  My only complaint is that it's only open until 9:30, which is usually when I've just finished dinner and am ready to go.

If you're driving (though I'm not sure this is a destination worth crossing the city for), you can usually find parking after 4:30 in front of Mission Dolores, and sometimes in front of the high school on 18th.  Tuesday nights are usually the best because street-cleaning on Dolores is Wednesday morning, so a lot of people have moved their cars.  Weekends you can park in the turn areas between the medians without fear of a ticket.
author: Gina K.

description: This is a great study spot. I love the free reliable wi fi.... decent sized tables... chill vibe.... and breakfast bagel. (If you order the breakfast bagel, have them melt the cheese.) The negatives... the people who work here are not friendly at all. I came in to grab a bite before work one day and the guy working the register flipped off a guy who was asking for a bag (as the guy was walking away). Not a nice way to start off your morning.
author: Natasha P.

description:
Pleasant music.
Bright, airy, but a lot of flies for some reason.
Coffee was just ok.
author: Peter O.

description:
I used to love this place and go here a lot to work, and then one day, I just stopped. Not sure why. The turkey club is really, really good. I miss it. 

But, I think the drawbacks are twofold, if you want to go someplace to get work done:

a) the music is totally unpredictable depending on who is behind the counter, and can sometimes be very loud and annoying.

b) the staff sometimes have a negative energy and don't seem to get along with each other that well, which can be distracting to someone (like me) who is sensitive to that kind of thing.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
PLUSES:  *BEER!!!!!!!!!!*; Great Coffee; Good soups & great hummus; varied food selection; Fun ambiance; upbeat music; friendly barristas; lots of regulars

MINUSES: Not enough outlets; wireless drops too frequently; can be fairly hot; sometimes fruit-flies launch a full-on attack

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
OK. I *LOVE* this cafe.  Great coffee (go for a hot soy latte), every Odwalla juice on the planet and BEER.  

I'm a big fan of the soup -- always tasty, with nice soft buttered rolls. 

The hummus is a good choice, as well.  

And oh did I mention BEER???  On tap, and in bottles.  Rock!

But, the REAL reason to come here (aside from the wifi, outdoor seating, great coffee and the 5-year-old regular) is the afternoon/evening barrista.  

I'm telling you, the music is teh bomb.  Fun, upbeat '90s stuff is on the current playlist.  Plus he's super-friendly and willing to jump around to New Order if you force the subject.  It makes working late a lot more pleasant.

Sadly, the wireless invariably drops at least once, if not more frequently, every time I'm there.  This is a royal pain in the ass if someone's trying to get work done. :/  

It seems hot when you first walk in, but it doesn't take long for the body to adjust and it's actually pretty comfortable, but it does seem hot at first.

I also suggest they change the soup offerings more often & deal with the fruit-fly problem:

1. pour bleach down all their drains
2. cover the bananas
3. leave out little dishes of vinegar mixed with dish soap to lure them to a watery grave
author: Dina G.

description: I came here with a friend to study for final exams. The owner and her assistant hovered over my friend and I while we prepared our study materials explaining on more than one occasion that we should buy something, pay her $1 USD an hour or leave. After I explained to both the owner and her assistant that we were aware of the policy and were planning on purchasing something immediately the owner began yelling about how her cafe is not a public park. She then continued on to exclaim that she is (in my own words) a greedy business owner. I've never felt so uncomfortable in a San Francisco cafe. OMG ftp.
author: Mohamad B.

description: I sat down with my friend (who bought a chai latte) and they kept reminding me that I have to purchase something to use WIFI. A lot of hustin for a cafe. It was Friday when there are a lot of seats open! Not cool.
author: Charles D.

description:
Beer on tap.  
OK coffee.  
Mint tea.  
Laundry next door.  
Free Internet.  
Outside seating under palm trees.  

A multi-hour mid-90s 3rd wave playlist?  AMAZING.  Here are some highlights:

Reel Big Fish: "Sell Out"
Mustard Plug: ""Thigh High Nylons"
Buck-o-Nine: "Pass The Dutchie" (Cover)
Less Than Jake: "Sugar In Your Gas Tank"
Pietasters: "Maggie Mae"

Wow.
author: Jon B.

description:
I ended up here because I didn't feel like going a church nearby with a friend for a Sunday service.   I needed more than a sermon to warm up my spirit on a rainy day.   I needed my third cup of coffee for the day. 

Good coffee.  Free wireless.  Spacious and clean.  There are also some vegan baked goods to choose from.  The two old couches by the window seemed ragged yet inviting.   The background music is super mellow - Norah Jones and others alike.   Unpretentious.  Simply cozy.

Will definitely go back if I am in the neighborhood again, or maybe next Sunday morning...
author: Shirley F.

description:
I used to be a semi regular here until my most recent experience. After reading some reviews I see that this is a bit of a pattern here.
So I brought my thermos in today to get filled as I usually do and I asked for a 16 ounce coffee which is the size of my thermos. 
I specifically asked for a 16 ounce coffee because I have been charged for the largest size coffee they have before because the thermos does look fairly large, however 16 ounces is stamped right on the side.
Anyway, the women who I think must be the owner took the thermos and returned it literally half full. I told her that I had asked for a 16 ounce coffee and the thermos says 16 ounce capacity on the side and why had she given me a half a cup of coffee.
She grumbled something about it looking larger.
Yes this is petty but really are you going to treat customers like this over 8 ounces of mediocre coffee. She then actually filled a 16 ounce coffee cup and poured it into my thermos just to make sure I was not cheating her out of an ounce to two of coffee, Wow.
Won't be back.
author: Peter M.

description: The windows are possibly the best thing going. It makes for an expansiveness and even indoors on a rain day, feels "campy." Creates a linger vibe when the Sunday Times is in hand or a great book has some chapters yet. But i can't say in this area where Samovar is a close stab for tea, or Philz aint far for strong joe, or Luna Park or Foreign Cinema is serving brunch, I find much behind the counter to bring me back. Someone did say the music is a little loud, and I shall agree. Its a subtle trumpet that will make brainwaves go delta, not one wailing for urgent attention @ the eardrum.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Seriously, this place knows how to make a cup of coffee, and the refills are c-h-e-a-p!

By far my favorite place to get a cup of coffee in the mission.  The ambiance, a la "big open warehouse with paintings" is great.  The seating is comfortable and plentiful.  And, best of all, the coffee here is really good.  Plus, they have bagels with lox- all the time!  

And, no kidding, I've had attentive, polite and fast service every time I've gone there.

The only drawback that I've had with this place is that they make said bagels with lox like a sandwich, instead of just arranging it all on a plate so that you can fix it how you want it.  And for some reason, they add sprouts.  But that's small potatoes.
author: Hannah N.

description: I love the open feel of this cafe, and it has a bohemian charm that is lacking from the Philz outpost on 18th Street.  Of course nothing beats the Philz Turkish, but Maxfield's provides a relaxed, comfortable atmosphere for working on your laptop (free wifi), chatting with a friend or reading a book.  It's doesn't feel as scene-y as Ritual.  Coming from New York, the bagels are pretty disappointing.  Too bready, and when I ordered the mine toasted it came back luke warm.  The cream cheese was slathered on inelegantly.  I haven't tried any of the other food, though the quiche looked delicious.  All in all a great place to hang out, but Philz, Ritual and Blue Bottle are still tops if you're all about the java.
author: Earl D.

description:
Good location, really nice place to relax in the weekend, they have some comfy chairs. They also have power sockets unlike Dolores Park Cafe so if your plan was to work, it is really conducive. Coffee ok, hot chocolate - great.
Nice health cookies, great atmosphere, free WiFi, parking is not too bad nearby..... definitely recommend
author: Belinda w.

description: I come here for the wireless, I have no idea about the singing barista but ever since I have been coming here everyone has been really nice. The location is perfect, nice seating outside, although the food is just ok everytime I order food I always regret it. Overall a good place to get some work done...
author: Jeanne R.

description:
this place definitely has some things going for it -- location, size (fairly spacious, plenty of tables), sidewalk seating, overall vibe. 

what it does not have going for it -- at least, not when i visited this afternoon -- was friendly service. i walked up, and the guy behind the counter just looked at me silently. no nod, no "hello," no "how can i help you," not even a twinge of a smile. just a blank, unfriendly stare.

thanks, dude -- way to make a good impression on your customers.
author: Elle B.

description:
I lived accross the street from this spot for about 10 years.  When it first opened I was nervous that it was destined to become just another boutique-ish yuppie hangout like the Dolores Park Cafe.  My cynical self was pleasantly surprised when it became a super-laid-back neighborhood spot.

Now that I've moved away, I miss Maxfield's more than I thought I would.  Although the food is generic and the coffee is so-so (although still better than the coffee here in Boston ... Dunkin Donuts as good coffee? What are people THINKING?), what I miss is the location, the people watching, and the convenience.  The cafe itself is bright and airy with plenty of tree-shaded outdoor seating, and most of the clientele consists of folks who acually live around that intersection, unlike the obnoxious throngs of tourists and marina residents that pack the DP Cafe a block away.  People bring their dogs and their kids here, play chess, and do their laundry next door at the star wash.  On weekends they have live Jazz and Bluegrass bands.  Throughout grad school I used to come here in the afternoon on warm days and have a beer while I studied.  Good times.
author: Matthew M.

description:
BORING.

it's a coffee shop. 

three stars because the seats aren't comfy, the walls had mediocre art, everything i touched was sticky, the coffee's regular, the staff are your everyday hipsters, and the crowd is a jungle of cafe lizards, some immobilized by their laptops, others immobilized by their cell phone.  yawn.

all in all, not that tragic or inspiring of a pit stop.  the place definitely induces apathy.  

apathy sounds like, "BLAH."
author: Carolyn H.

description:
One of the best days of my life happened at Maxfields, and for that, I will forever hold it in a special place in my mind.

In addition, I have spent many a sunny day sipping coffee, chomping on bagels and working under the shady tree outside. And many a not-so-wonderful day inside as well. 

I like Maxfield's coffee too. A lot of coffee does a number on my stomach - make it feel like it's burning from the inside out - but not Maxfields. I hear this may be related to acid levels. I have no idea. All I know is that Maxfield's coffee does not do this to me.

Finally, Maxfield's has beer on tap for relatively cheap and sometimes has jazz in the evenings. It's an all around good, unpretentious place.
author: Jen B.

description:
I GOT MY LAPTOP TAKEN FROM ME RIGHT FROM MY LAP AT THIS CAFE. For that I'm giving this establishment and my experience a Big Fat 0.  Now, when this happened to me, I chased the inbred shitfucker outside the cafe and one of the employees who caught on ran out right behind me.  He and a random pedestrian grabbed the inbred shitfucker, struggled with him and I got my laptop back. Of course, after it fell to ground and cracked my LCD monitor.  But I got it back.  The kid got away in a convertible waiting outside with 3 other inbred muthafuckas in it.

And before I could even let the incident sink in, the owner and a patron inside  were on the phone calling the police.  For this and for my hero employee and pedestrian, I give a BIG FAT 5.  Which averages to 3.

Watch yo shit everyone!  Invest in those cable locks!
author: I love t.

description:
Pros:
1. They serve wine and beer, including a few on tap.  
2. Free wireless internet.
3. The ambience... there are four outdoor sidewalk tables in a beautiful part of the neighborhood, and the interior is comfortable with lots of wooden tables and a few couches near the huge windows.
4. Service is friendly.
5. They're located exactly next door to the laundromat that I use.

Cons:
1. The wine selection is limited to "red" or "white", causing me to wonder if I've accidentally wandered outside SF city limits.
2. The baked items I've purchased have ended up left on top of the garbage recepticle outside.
3. The coffee is drinkable but pales in comparison to some of the terrific coffee you can get elsewhere in the neighborhood (Ritual is the prime example).
4. Service is pretty slow for a coffee house.
5. They stopped selling sangria a while back.  Boooo!
author: DemonPixie ..

description:
Located on Dolores and 17th, and there is adequate parking in the surrounding area. 

I work a fair bit from coffee shops so my main concerns are having a decent  wireless connection and enough space to sit and work. Both of these requirements are taken care off. There are plenty of tables both outside and inside and the internet connection is good enough for me. There are also a lot of electricical connection points for those who need to connect to a power source for their laptops which is great for me.

I'm not exactly a coffee conassieur but the coffee could be better. However they do have a decent selection of drinks, sandwiches and snacks

Pros:
1. Good enough WiFi connection
2. Adequate seating
3. Plenty of seating available
4. Enough power outlets

Cons:
1. No credit cards
2. Food isn't great
author: Krishnan S.

description:
Once again I must reiterate my want to have 1/2 star ratings...I would rate this place at 2 1/2...So I rounded up.

I'm in this neighborhood just about every morning...the few times I've stepped into Maxfield's I've left feeling not-so-great.

I think the main reason for this is staffing - and this is two fold:
-There is usually only one person working in the morning...so between taking orders and making food & coffee, the wait tends to be a little much.
-The other part of this is that the staff haven't been particularly stellar in the attitude department. I usually walk in there with a happy face on and feeling pretty peppy, but the response is a rushed, "take your order and get you out of my face" kind of thing.

The coffee is so-so...slightly weak, a bit bitter. 

The ambience isn't all that friendly here...I like to get my coffee and leave. 

Food - I've only had the breakfast croissant which was very yummy.

Prices - Hefty. $3+ for a double is a lot IMO. 

I'm not completely done with Maxfield's...I'd like to go back a time or two in the hope that they have some redeeming qualities I've yet to see.

...to be continued?
author: Sonia P.

description: I am in LOVE with the the singing barista!!!  What a bunch of haters on here, hating on someone who obviously is enjoying life and tries to bring a little fun into your lives!!  You keep it up babe!!
author: Melanie P.

description: The location is nice, the coffee is good, never had any problems with the people there, but the best thing about this place is they are pooch friendly. My poodle mix can relax at my feet in the cafe, while I drink coffee and check the internet.
author: Andrew D.

description: Nice place that is very convenient to Dolores Park and the hipster chaos that lies within -- at least for us this Sunday. My iced tea was more than serviceable. The atmosphere was chill and led to several epiphanies. Adam was happy too. We'll be back.
author: Allison L.

description: I refuse to go to this place so I will never know how cool it might be or how amazing the coffee is. Back when they were first opening they went to my buddy Joel's coffee shop, on the same block and asked him for help because they were going to open a corner market. He helped them and told them all about his business. Well, we all know that Maxfield's House of Caffeine was never intended to sell pampers and Campbell's soup. Slim shady owners. So I'm boycotting their ass and you should too.
author: Phil M.

description: hot pastrami had huge thick cuts of pastrami......yes yes and yes
author: Rob C.

description: Always packed with a gaggle of coffee lovers who appear to be studying for their exams. Or maybe just blogging about themselves. Whatever they're doing, there's a friendly university-esque atmosphere to Maxfield's, topped off by the computers offering Web access. I love its proximity to Dolores Park. Delicious pastries and above-average biscotti.  Will also whip up a good sandwich.
author: Andrew K.

description: nice to have a place that has good selection of caffeine as well as some alcohol, not to mention some eats. wish the wifi was a bit more stable.
author: Ryan T.

description: I would say that Maxfields is just your general non-descript coffee shop in the Mission.  There is nothing about it that stands out in particular, except that it is only one block from Dolores Park, and therefore quite convenient.
author: Joanna S.

description:
maxfields didnt disappoint me today! it was my first time to chillax there.. since i want to discover more than the dolores cafe, which is a block away from maxfields AND MY FAVE PARK IN THE WORLD! :D yay.. anyways, i had a thai iced tea (taste like any other thai iced tea that i had before.. lol), a veggie frittata (kinda rubbery?), an iced hot chocolate (YAY!), and a vegan oatmeal choco chip cookie! 

pretty much stayed there and did my school stuffs from 11 up to 4:30ish; hence, the orders that i did! :) 

the cafe is very spacious, and there are tables to sit on, BUT......
i just have to complain about the outlet for laptops.. they're clustered into one place, which is the whole wooden bench on the wall. the outlets need to disperse! :P ................. wifi is great, and i laave the neighborhood as usual! homey and quaint! gotta go here when sun is up! hopefully when i get back there, i meet a guy there! teeheeeeee.. :3

PS: the guy that works there is SOOO CUTE, but this one time he didnt give me my change, it doesnt bother me.. he's just nice to look at.. and OH! he complements you in an uncanny way! LOL
author: Marc K.

description: When Dolores Park sun starts to give me a few too many freckles, Maxfield's becomes the office. Free wi-fi, deliciously spicy soy chai lattes, the best vegan cookies ever and they never kicked me out for falling asleep on the couch. All this in addition to friendly service and the possibility of a BLT make Maxfield's top notch.
author: Tory S.

description:
Free wifi access with no passwords to mess with and copious power outlets: Awesome!

Food and drink selection: Middle of the road

Barista dude singing loudly (and poorly) along with half the songs: TERRIBLE.

There's a reason I don't sing in public.  This guy needs to discover that reason.

Made me have a strong desire to finish up what I was doing and GTFO.
author: Sam E.

description: Maxfields has awesome food but the the staff members are on the shakey side.Some of the staff members are nice but some are the opposite of nice.The brownies at Maxfields are probably the richest brownies in SF and they taste good dipped in their delicious hot chocolate.I hear that the coffee there is pretty good.Maxfields also has fantabulous rice crispy treats and there is free Wi-Fi connection.Maxfields is also pretty pricey.
author: Nikki Y.

description: I'm sitting at Maxfield's as I'm writing this. Jangling cacophony that seems appropriate as the ambiance for a caffeine fix. Dogs, laptops, affable chatter, aroma of bagels, slightly grungy floor, chalked blackboards colorfully suggesting an array of drinks and pastries...and lunch. This is the perfect set for describing the typical SF/Mission coffee house. Everything you expect to find and the expected satisfaction are all here. Good (tho not great) coffee is here. Friendly gals behind the counter. A mixture of music...classic R&B and 60s blues as I write this...is the wallpaper behind fifty conversations. A clutch of tables out front watching the church parking empty out. All is fine.
author: Gary C.

description: The bagel I got here today was terrible and there was a fly inside the display case. The woman behind the counter was pleasant, however the music was a little too loud. I can't say I'd recommend going here.
author: Kevin O.

description: This is on my regular cafe circuit, but I only go there when I care more about free wi-fi, ample table space and power outlets, and less about the quality of food.  I like the sometimes nerdy hipster crowd.  Also, the place is full of light and has a few sidewalk tables for nice days.
author: Katherine W.

description: Hmmm...it's a little hot and sweltering in here.  Lots of flies.  It's kinda tropical, with the rattan furniture.  I think I'm in the Philippines.
author: Jenn A.

description:
just another face in the crowd. maxfield serves average coffee that's indistinguishable from other coffee houses. however, when dolores park cafe gets a little too crazy, maxfield is a decent alternative. this cafe should really deserve 2.5 stars, but i'll round it up to 3 stars cuz it's not as fancy or trendy as ritual and dolores park cafe. i like that.

bonus. if you're at dolores park and you need to go pee and dolores park cafe has a line out the door, walk over one block to maxfield. there should be minimal wait for the bathroom. and yes, you have to buy something.
author: frisco j.

description: With everybody having orgasms over Ritual, lest we forget the real king of coffee shops in the Mission: Maxfield's. Nice out-of-the-way location, but just a block away from Dolores Park, there's solid coffee and food, plus beer! The crowd is pretty much the standard fare as every other coffee shop in the environs: Mac laptops, horn-rimmed glasses, girls with short hair, whatever. But the space is airy, feels homey, and is overall unpretentious. Only downside: who knew that a tuna/turkey/ham sandwich included only one and not all of those meats?
author: Kai H.

description: Great spot, worked here many a day, only problem is that it gets a too crowded.  i guess that's just a city-wide problem, too many laptops in any coffee shop...
author: Max H.

description: I have no idea why but this place manages to hold my title for best chai latte in the city. Also, they have phenomenal little breads next to the counter (strawberry, zucchini, pumpkin, etc).  Yup, this place is tasty.
author: Melissa Y.

description: I've recently been reintroduced to the world of "having to study" and Maxfield's quickly became my favorite spot to do so. Good coffee, the music isn't too loud and the ambiance is cozy. The wifi seems pretty fast too.
author: Blake R.

description: I come here with my laptop mostly because it's only a block away and I need a change of scenery from the inside of my office every now and then.  The coffee is okay.  Some days the wi-fi works great, and other days it drops out every 20 minutes or so.  Convenience trumps quality.
author: Howard K.

description: I have to admit, I am sitting at Maxfields right now waiting for a client and I have to say, it is a really pleasant experience.  There is tons of natural light infiltrating the place,  cool people meeting, talking and typing away on their laptops, unique art on the wall, and overall it has a pretty cool vibe. I don't think I would go out of my way to return, but if I am in the neighborhood, I would definitely stop in again.
author: Amanda L.

description: very friendly staff. the guy who made our drinks was great, he was singing along to music and was quite pleasant. the mocha was good for a mocha...i am not a huge coffee drinker so it  was ok, i wish it was more chocalatey but maybe I should just get hot chocolate. I got an italian soda after, it was good. lots of flavor. my friend's chai latte was good. i felt at ease. the furniture was an ok comfort. i enjoyed the 90's alternative music..and classics like "closing time". it was nostalgic. i was inspired to com ehere and do work on my laptop. i would go back. close to dolores park which is good too and it is good when dolores park cafe is already closed.
author: Steph W.

description:
the wifi-nomad, here again!  my last few posts are local cafes with...you guessed it...FREE WIFI b/c that has become my quest as of late...

so i don't think i've ever eaten anything here, i just get coffee or tea, but i like the vibe, i always get a table close to a power outlet, and always see a cute boy or 2 - a nice distraction when i'm working hard on the laptop.  and it's a place i feel like i can go to the john and leave all my shit out and not come back to an empty table.  AND i don't smell like fried food when i step out of this joint (read The Grind review).  just just a block from Dolores Park too...
author: Suzanne A.

description: Nice, open, inviting place.  I love their sun-dried tomatoes cream cheese - but their bagels were bad enough to not enjoy it.
author: Audrey L.

description: If you need a place to take your laptop during the day this works quite well. Free wifi, much quieter than that place on the corner of Dolores Park, and with more electric outlets too. Food not quite as good perhaps, but they do have a few beers on tap in case that early morning coffee wasn't exactly what you were looking for. Staff seem pretty friendly.
author: Stuart J.

description: I'm sorry to report that after many visits here, in my opinion it sn't that great. Dull atmosphere, super dull and slow barrista's, nothing special coffee or espresso and (god, is she really the owner? because she doesn't seem to have it together enough for this kind of business.) And after reading Phil M's review all I can say is that this is a good spot to go pee when the line is too long at Dolores Pk Cafe. (like during the dyke march.) My hope for this place is that some other person buys it and makes it better. I don't think D. Pk Cafe will suffer much from the competition.  They're doing well.
author: Roanna Z.

description: Wi-Fi's a bit shifty, rice crispy treats are meh but the tea is excellent and the atmosphere is cozy.
author: Jessica L.

description:
There is so much competition especially in this area so you have to be, more than good , and for me the coffee is the single most important factor.  I've been in this place four times since I moved back here, 2 for 4, 
I got a better than good Americano.  For the record, a standard americano is 2 shots with some hot water.  The barista should ask the customer how much water he or she wants.  Otherwise why wouldn't we just order a coffee?  Twice my drink was served in a porcelain mug and I was asked how much water I wanted so the drink was tasty, good, heavy body, just enough water, just short of an eight ounce cup, some crema on top, not intentional but appreciated.  Twice I was charged for a double americano and was served some brown water in a huge, maybe 20 ounce clear glass, the kind you would use for iced tea or drinking water.
Yucky.  I had noticed that both times the house mugs, nice size for me were there waiting to be filled.  The ladies there are really nice and fast, the guy was kind of dismissive, lots of tables and you can even sit outside and diddle on the net or watch the parade of hipsters go by, so for service and atmosphere it's definitely a 5.  I heard that a stellar coffee concession will be going into Dolores Park, not down for it but maybe I can get  an americano that's consisitently good.
author: Teri K.

description: I love the atmosphere here.  The staff is friendly without being overly solicitous and they do a good job with espresso drinks.
author: Robert M.

description: This is my favorite coffee house in San Francisco because it is a REAL coffee house. People drink coffee and just hang out in a big open space at Maxfields. The Indian wraps and club sandwich aren't too bad either. But hearing Dolly Parton on the cd player is what sold me.
author: Sara L.

description: The coffee shop itself is cozy but the wait staff is very "you-should-kiss-my-feet-for-serving-you-nevermind-the-fact-that-its-my-JOB".  I love it when the counter staff assumes I'm going to tip them 50 cents on a $1.50 cup of tea and therefore drops my change in to the tip jar before even handing it to me.  To be fair he saw how surprised I was that he assumed and tried to make it up but really, it's just silly to assume.  In the end I'm not that hard up that I NEED the 50 cents but hey man!  That's laundry quarters!!!
author: Alexis B.

description: You won't get dirty looks for lugging your Dell around, but you will surely crave a mac after chillin' here. I didn't have any food or coffee here, but a hot cocoa instead and it wasn't bad at all. The service was similar to other coffee houses and my barista was Mandonna's go-go dancer, cool.
author: Charm N.

description:
I really dig this cafe. I'm one of those laptop nomads who lives in the area and Maxfields is one of my regular places to eat and work. 

The pluses:
* Mellow, mellow vibe (I love mellow, kick-back, casual cafes). I'm not there for a "scene" or anything in-your-face.
* The cafe interior is airy with high-ceilings (unlike some of the more cramped cafes in the area). There are large windows fronting Dolores St. and so the cafe gets a good amount of natural light. In fact, on sunny days, you might want to avoid the couches adjacent the windows as you'll get a ton of laptop glare.
* The staff is nice
* They have a lot of vegan options (if you're into that). The vegan cookies and breads (banana, pumpkin, etc) are very tasty -- and I'm not even vegan.
* Outlets are pretty easy to get to if you know where to sit
* I've never had a problem getting a seat here
* Nice mix of patrons: You get all sorts here. Startup people, kids, D&D dudes...the whole lot. Nice change from some of the more homogeneous spots where it's row after row of laptop peoples.

Minuses:
* Coffee is decent, not great (this is Jumpin' Java Cafe level coffee -- don't expect your Blue Bottle experience here)
* Sometimes you'll get a singing barista. Doesn't bug me so much, but there's one dude in the afternoon that likes to sing along to his ipod playlists.

Public Service Announement: If you're a nomadic startup guy, like me, who frequents cafes. Please do your part to SUPPORT the cafe. Buy stuff, tip 'em, make room for other patrons if you have room at your table and the place is full. I say this partly out of guilt, since I vowed since Canvas died to be a better cafe citizen in the future (r.i.p. Canvas Cafe -- we used and abused you to death)
author: David P.

description: A few friends and I went down to Maxfield's for something a bit different than the cafes in the Castro.  It's a good environment, good location, great place to people watch from inside or outside, and the coffee is pretty good.  I recommend the Breakfast Bagel!
author: Jonathan C.

description: This place is pretty cool, with lots of outlets for computer folks, and I'd rate their sandwiches at the high end, in terms of coffee shop food.   But, jeez, learn how to toast a bagel.
author: Ted M.

description: Has there been a change of ownership?  I didn't see any singing baristas or rude staff behind the counter on my first time visit today--as reported by earlier yelpers.  Nice high ceiling, airy large interior, soft and hard seating, plenty of space, good array of vegan cookies, fine soy latte and quick service.,
author: Bob G.

description: Good solid local coffee joint.  Yummy food...best breakfast bagel ever. Nice assortment of goodies, even vegan options.  Coffee is great, order "for here" and you actually get to drink out of a mug, go figure. Plus wine and beer, loving it.  You can pop in and out when you're out and about, or leisurely drink while reading or surfing the Net.  2 computers or WiFi provided. And always some rocking beats in the background.
author: Caitlin J.

description: I regularly walk an extra block or so to get coffee and read at Maxfield's.  The corner location, big front windows, high ceiling, and pretty good snack assortment put it a good step above the average corner coffee spot.  Let's be honest, coffee shops in this city are a dime a dozen, and compete many of them seem to become extreme environments.  To me, Maxfield's is a great balance - funky employees, good vibe, nice mix of other customers, and pleasant space.
author: philip k.

description: Ahhh, another cozy coffee shop near Dolores Park.  The coffee's decent and the treats are pretty damn good.  And a great wifi connection!
author: Elaine U.

description:
i'm goin to give this place five stars.  why, you may ask?  because i can chill out here with a beverage and actually get reading done.  just a good neighborhood coffee shop without the boy watching or pretentiousness you may find at the nearest starbucks.  i like the service and the baristas who sing with the music.  ive had the coffee cake, vege burrito, turkey sandwhich, bagel and cream cheese.  food is eehhh...  i don't go for the food.. just the atmosphere and study environment. 

they need new couches.
author: Ann M.

description: A friendly, serviceably coffee shop good for internet surfing, quiet conversations, and especially avoiding the crowds at Dolores Park Cafe.
author: Leslie H.

description: Great place to study.  Love the bagel egg and cheese with a cup of iced coffee.  Very good light.
author: Liz E.

description:
Nothing particularly special here - bake goods, coffee, tea, and service are acceptable.  

It is a great spot to study I have to say.  Free wireless and plenty of room.  Doesn't seem to ever get too crowded, even on a Sunday.
author: Minny W.

description:
This is a great cafe. Great location (a block from dolores park), coffee is ok, nice light, plenty of free wifi and electricity, a good place to work, blah blah blah.

However...

It's OK for a cafe to play crap 90's rock. Sometimes. But.  It is completely UNNECESSARY (in my opinion) for baristas to sing along! I come to this cafe a lot since I moved to the neighborhood, and so far I've witnessed two different baristas serenading an unwilling audience.

I'm really surprised other reviewers haven't mentioned this bizarre feature.  Stop singing boys! (Pretty please?)
author: Jonathan B.

description: There are a lot of people who come here with their laptops but it's not one of those "shut the f--- up I'm doing something really important" places.  I think people should go to the library, a church, or home if they want peace quiet in a public place.  Maxfield's is totally unpretentious, spacious, has great coffee, and yummy sandwiches.  Good place to chill for a long time.  ...and you're allowed to have a conversation.
author: regina k.

description: Well.  I have officially arrived on the yelp scene.  So here it goes.  This retro-70's coffee house is my favorite coffee house in the dolores park neighborhood.  While the quality of the mocha's vary quite a bit (why did you leave John), the atmosphere is relaxing.  You can find me outside on a sunny day.  I love the feel of the warm sunshine on my skin as the coffee warms me from the inside out.  I have had several in-depth conversations here with the dolores park locals.  Overall, a great place to read the paper, work on your computer, study, or just about anything else you want to do at a coffee shop.  ;)
author: Brandon C.

description: simple, straight-forward coffee shop with no frills.  I like that people actually talk in this cafe, it's not a zombie-land of computer addicts.  a good place to while away hours chatting, studying, reading, or computer-ing.  I spent years here studying for a series of exams - in the evenings, when there wasn't so much singing going on, but I wore earplugs so i could focus.  nice location.
author: Northanger A.

description: I live in the neighborhood and tire of 'the herd' on 18th St. that swarms to Dolores Park Cafe, Bi Rite Creamery, and the 40 minute line at Tartine.  Maxfield's is the real neighborhood cafe and I walk the extra block to hang here.  Strong coffee, funky cool, mellow vibe and music.  Not a sleek cafe.  Big plus is that it's nice and toasty on cold rainy days.  Wireless is flawless and a great student/artist crowd that's totally mellow along with the great neighborhood kids who just come in after school.  Love this place, but you gotta love funky.
author: Sam C.

description: A fine coffeeshop if you live in the neighborhood.  However, not too special.  Coffee is fine, food is fine, and atmosphere is fine.  I go here if I need quarters or if I need to get out of the house and read the onion.  Meh.
author: Mira B.

description: I loved coming here with my dog after a walk through Dolores Park. I tried to work here on my laptop a few times - but for me the idea is better than reality as I work 10x faster at my desk. I don't remember anything special about the coffee - it was hot and tasted like coffee. They have an A-OK selection of cookies and things. I just like it here every now and again - it's low key, near the park and they have free wireless which I won't really use anymore.
author: Jack K.

description:
Moved to this very fun neighborhood six months ago and discovered this great place.  The owner and team get an A for customer service.
Sitting outside is fun as you watch all the colorful people in our hood.
author: Demetri A.

description: I stumbled upon Maxfield's on my way to the Dyke March in Dolores Park.  Tired and thirsty, Maxfield's was an oasis.  Loved the latte and the banana bread.  Nice, homey interior.  Much better than any Starbuck's.  Only drawback: only one bathroom that can accommodate a single person.  The line was long.
author: Bob B.

description:
one star for the fact that if i ever WANT to be ignored and then talked down to by the staff at a coffee house i know the perfect little place to get my dose of attitude--yummy!
and one star for the fact that in retrospect it was almost entertaining how farcical the staff really was.....

so, i walk into maxfield's. i go to the fridge and take out a vitamin water (back off!--i LOVE vitamin water). i bring my bottle of flavored sugar liquid to the counter and stand there with my bottle and a $20 in the air in front of me while 2 employees SIT on the sandwich counter (note to self: never order food here. it will be prepared on the same surface as the employees put their asses) for 10 minutes watching this:

skateboard guy: hmm...should i get green or black tea?
babyshirt/nail polish/bad hair dye guy: what do you like better (flirt flirt flirt)
skateboard guy: (totally ignoring the flirt) wweeeellllll....how much caffeine is in them?
babyshirt/nail polish/bad hair dye guy: (insert diatribe about caffeine levels that skateboard guy makes a point of rudely ignoring)
skateboard guy: i don't know....
babyshirt/nail polish/bad hair dye guy: what do you drink at home? do you brew your own tea at home?
skateboard guy: green tea i guess...hmmm
babyshirt/nail polish/bad hair dye guy: ok then, would you like that or would you like to try something new? (eyebrows flicker up and down)
skateboard guy: (ignoring eyebrows) i'll take the green tea....wait, no....
babyshirt/nail polish/bad hair dye guy: well...
skateboard guy: (looking over at boobs popping out girl's boobs) what should i get?
boobs popping out girl: what do you like best? i like...
skateboard guy: (interrupting boobs popping out girl) i'll take the green tea.
babyshirt/nail polish/bad hair dye guy: ok, (leans over counter--seriously) coming right up!
boobs popping out girl: totally good call.
skateboard guy: yeah....
babyshirt/nail polish/bad hair dye guy rings up skateboard guy's lame ass safe cup of tea and WALKS AWAY FROM THE COUNTER!
me: (still standing like an idiot with my bottle--half drunk--and my $20) drops jaw!!!
new counter person chick who was sitting on the counter behind babyshirt/nail polish/bad hair dye guy this whole time comes up to the register. looks at me....
new counter person chick: you want to buy THAT?
1. i already drank half
2. why would i do that if i didn't want it in the first place never mind the fact that i voluntarily took it out of the fridge myself.
and 3...the most important!!!!......IF YOU ARE SO FUCKING SNOTTY ABOUT SELLING VITAMIN WATER THEN DON'T FUCKING SELL VITAMIN WATER!!!

i will probably never go back unless i need to break another $20.....
author: Bad Ass Chic K.

description: super into the aesthetics of this place. the way all the tables are positioned feels nice. or maybe it's the plants, plants are good to be around too. i sat here for like an hour and a half or something. the sun dried tomato cream cheese tasted weird but i don't like cream cheese that much anyways.
author: Sara M.

description: i love it when cozy cafes have coffee AND beer AND free wi-fi. this combination makes me jump for joy! and Maxfield's is one such place. so here i am taking a break from helping the sweetie with grading mid-term exams on an overcast saturday. maxfield's is full of bustle: folks on computers, folks reading various media, folks drinking coffee, tea, beer, what have you, folks just having a snack. yup. pretty chill spot. the menu includes the usual cafe fare - bagels and pastries and such.
author: ray e.

description: i like the feel of this place, and they also happen to have marsha's marvelous wraps, which i just love!
author: Jill k.

description: the coffee here tastes burnt. and the employees in the morning are generally unpleasant.  i wish i liked it, it's RIGHT across from my house, but i just feel like they have no personality there, other than the photos on the wall, which i like quite well.
author: lauren a.

description: Buggy, dusty seats, and overall feels grimy. Coffee is oh so so-so. The wifi is mighty flaky too. A pity, because the location is great. The best way to make the best of this place is to sit outside.
author: Shwin S.

description: seriously, this place might get another star if it weren't for the AWFUL music. i just listened to a song twang on about tractors. seriously, WTF. country? like, real twangy backwoods country? in mission dolores? one important thing i have learned about art and writing that would seem to be applicable here would be to consider your audience. looking around at my fellow cafe goers, i see rows and rows of mac books, young, creative, well- educated, white collar office types, and not a single pair of wranglers or a raised-suspension truck anywhere in sight. now, some may tolerate or even enjoy a country song here and there, for ironic or nostalgic purposes, but this is really too much. maxfields, i implore you: change the music!! if you are thinking about coming by, bring your headphones, even when they aren't playing country, thier musical selection is pretty stale. at least it has been since i have been here...
author: meagan m.
